courses.description: (UGEB1217 is double-coded with BMEG1217.)  This course exposes students to a range of state-of-the-arts developments in biomedical engineering. It invites students from various disciplines to discuss the long-term societal impacts and ethical implications of these technological advances, particularly in human enhancements beyond therapy. The course starts by illustrating the many amazing designs in our human body and yet how vulnerable we are in terms of injuries, diseases and ageing. Examples on how modern biomedical engineering helps us face our human conditions are given, such as musculoskeletal prosthetics and orthotics, cardiovascular implants, neuroengineering, stem cells and regenerative medicine, gene editing, bionanotechnology, intelligence and artificial intelligence and senses and artificial senses, etc. A historical account of human quest for “living” machine, including a brief coverage of modern movies on bionic human then follows. The course wraps up with some social, ethical and philosophical reflections on the above issues and on the meaning of being human, opening up questions concerning the perennial human quest of becoming super human.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB1217 is double-coded with BMEG1217. 
Not for Biomedical Engineering Majors; and students who have taken BMEG1217. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of the subject, students will be able to:
Describe some of the amazing designs in human body & their potential damages due to injuries, diseases, & ageing;
Give examples on how engineering has helped in reconstructing damaged body parts and/or body functions, such as musculoskeletal prosthetics, cardiovascular implants, artificial sight, tissue & genetic engineering, etc.;
Reflect on our human imagination about the bionic human of the future; and
Discuss some of the philosophical, societal and ethical issues associated with such technological development.
Higher-Order Learning
and
Literacy
: Students will be given sets of thematic reading assignments (listed as common reading requirements in the Reading List and Reference section), and asked to question, discuss, and illustrate their readings using some instructor-prepared worksheets as guides. Throughout the subject, students will be drawn to reflect on their views on the distinct characteristics of being human. Each student is expected to critically review one of the selected books (given in the Reading List, total reading not less than 200 pages) in a book report (~2,500 words).
Life-Long Learning
: In this interdisciplinary subject, students will be constantly facilitated and drilled to learn across their disciplines. We regard such an interdisciplinary learning capacity an important skill for life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Human life is both amazing and vulnerable. Amazing – the designs and working of our human bodies are the envies of engineering science. Vulnerable – the best and the strongest are still mortal. We are susceptible to trauma, diseases, ageing and finally death. Advances in life science and engineering are bringing to us in fast cadence and big strides innovative breakthroughs and new possibilities in healing and rejuvenation, functional recoveries and health enablement. Powered intelligent prostheses for subjects with amputation, fully implantable artificial hearts for subjects with heart failures, tissue engineered skin for severely burnt subjects, stem cells therapies for impaired brain tissues are examples that our body can be fixed by replacing the defective components with artificial “spare parts” and other augmentative measures. At the same time, research laboratories are developing intelligent robots that can see, hear, smell, talk, walk, dance, think, and feel like human – following a centuries-long human quest for “living” machines. The mechanistic implications of these biomedical and engineering advances seem apparent – Is human a robot? Can robot one day become human? The artists among us are quick to perceive and even exploit these implications. The entertainment media have imaginatively presented many kinds of human-robotic hybrids, both as heroes and villains, often with power and abilities beyond those of a human. What could we tell about ourselves from our quests, pursuits, and dreams? How may one define the borderline between human and robot? What does it mean to be a human?

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Energy and Green Society
courses.description: This course is designed to help students to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the global energy crisis and environmental issues our society is currently facing. The history of energy consumption shows how important energy is to the quality of life for the human beings. With the further development and the increase of the world population, our society is challenged by an unprecedented energy demand in 21st century. At the same time, the global warming and climate changes are also causing more and more attentions. How can we meet the future energy demand? What are the energy options we currently have and what are their impacts on the environment? How can we meet our energy needs without deteriorating the environment? The first half of this course will tackle the above-raised questions by examining our current energy options and their respective impacts on the environment. Then, to address both the energy and environmental concerns, possible routes to develop a green society will be discussed in the second half of this course with a focus on renewable energy resources, smart grid, eco-friendly vehicles, and carbon sequestration and carbon audit. Lab experiments are expected to be conducted to formulate and design several different renewable energy systems toward constructing a green society. This course is relevant to SDG #7 “Affordable and Clean Energy”, SDG #9 “Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure”, and SDG #13 “Climate Action”. (No technical background is required)
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Energy Engineering; Energy and Environmental Engineering; and Mechanical and Automation Engineering Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Energy Magic - The Wonders of Chemistry and Environmental Conservation
courses.description: This course will take students into the magical world of energy, exploring the role of chemistry in energy production and environmental conservation. We will introduce different types of energy, from conventional fossil fuels to renewable sources, and understand their manufacturing, conversion, and utilization processes. In addition, we will discuss the environmental issues faced by modern society, such as climate change and air pollution, and explore how chemistry can provide solutions.Climate change and air pollution are closely related to energy. For examples, fossil fuel combustion can produce greenhouse gas (e.g. carbon dioxide CO2) that contribute to global warming. Combustion also produces sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (PM) that can harm air quality and public health.This course includes lectures, class discussion, group presentation and project report of selected topic, and final examination.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for majors in Faculty of Science; not for students of IDA+X Double Maj.Prog., ASEI+X Double Maj.Prog., MASE+X Double Maj.Prog.,; and students who have taken UGEB2381.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
To learn different forms of energy and their applications in daily life.
To understand how chemistry helps us convert energy from one form to another.
To acquire knowledge about the composition and properties of petroleum, the extraction process, and the manufacturing of petroleum products. They will also understand the environmental impact associated with petroleum usage.
To study various renewable energy sources, including as solar, wind, and hydroelectric power. They will understand the principles behind these technologies, such as their advantages and the challenges associated with their implementation.
To gain knowledge about different energy storage technologies, including chemical batteries and fuel cells. They will understand the working principles and applications of these technologies.
To explore the role of chemistry in promoting sustainable energy and environmental conservation.
To evaluate human’s role in the society that can help in environmental protection, and the impact of these issues on human life.
courses.course_syllabus:
There will be totally six topics for this course, and each topic will spend one to two teaching weeks. A group presentation of selected topic will be applied for a part of final assessment in this course.
(Week 1) Topic 1: Fundamentals of Energy
- Definition and classification of energy
- Applications of energy in everyday life
- The role of chemistry in energy conversion
(Week 2-3) Topic 2: Chemical Reactions and Energy Conversion
- Basic principles of chemical reactions
- Generation and conversion of heat energy
- Applications of chemical reactions in energy conversion
(Week 4-5) Topic 3: Petroleum Chemistry
- Composition and properties of petroleum
- Petroleum extraction processes
- Manufacturing of petroleum products and environmental impact
(Week 6-7) Topic 4: Renewable Energy
- Principles and technologies of solar energy utilization
- Applications of wind and hydroelectric power
- Advantages and challenges of renewable energy
(Week 8-9) Topic 5: Batteries and Energy Storage
- Structure and working principles of chemical batteries
- Applications of lithium batteries, fuel cells, etc.
- Development and applications of energy storage technologies
(Week 10-11) Topic 6: Environmental Conservation and Sustainable Energy
- Current status and challenges of environmental issues
- The role of chemistry in reducing environmental impact
- Trends and policies in sustainable energy development
(Week 12-13) Group Project Presentation
- About 2-3 students in a group
- Select a topic for a presentation in 10-15 minutes for each group

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Demystifying Artificial Intelligence

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 401

courses.description: (UGEB1407 is double-coded with ENGG1910.) Artificial intelligence (AI) is not only one of the most influential technologies nowadays but also a hot topic for the general public. Today’s AI technology is built upon profound mathematical and scientific knowledge, and a full array of engineering innovations. This introductory course on AI is designed for undergraduate students majoring in non-engineering subjects. Students taking the course are assumed to have minimal background in mathematics and no experience in computer programming. Students will learn the basic elements of artificial intelligence, data analytics, and machine learning, and develop in-depth understanding of notable applications of AI, for example, face recognition, talking robots, synthetic media, art creation, sentiment analysis. A large part of the learning activities will be in the forms of technology demonstrations, laboratory practice, project design and group discussion.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB1407 is double-coded with ENGG1910. 
Not majors in Faculty of Engineering; IDA+X Double Maj Prog; ASEI+X Double Maj Prog; MASE+X Double Maj Prog; and students who have taken ENGG1910.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix.
courses.course_syllabus:
Modern digital computers – Basic principles of digital computers; High-performance computing for AI applications
Computing algorithms – What constitute a computing algorithm? How algorithms can be used to solve complex problems
Data, information and knowledge – Relation between data, information and knowledge; How to represent different types of information by data; How to discover useful knowledge from data; How to make decisions based on data
Basic concepts of machine learning – Learning from data; classification and regression; supervised and unsupervised learning; feature extraction; model training
Software and hardware in AI – Basic software and hardware requirements for AI technology development; AI software environment, platforms and tools
Notable applications of AI – Computer vision; Image recognition; Speech recognition; Natural language processing; Machine translation; Image and speech generation; Hands-on experiments on the use of selected AI technology
Ethical and environmental issues in AI – Data privacy; Bias and discrimination; Human rights; Transparency; Safety; Energy consumption

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence in Action
courses.description: (UGEB1408 is double-coded with ENGG1920.) Artificial intelligence (AI) refers broadly to the technologies that enable computing machines to perform tasks that are believed to require human intelligence.  Nowadays AI is widely applied not only to solve high-complexity real-world problems but also to provide powerful tools to assist our day-to-day work and living. The objectives of this course are to let students experience the use of AI, and encourage them to apply AI in their interested areas. Students will learn the basic principles, the functions, the performance and limitation of main types of AI technologies. Through guided programming practice and design project, students will gain hands-on experience on using AI software tools, evaluating existing technologies and creating new applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB1408 is double-coded with ENGG1920.
Not for majors in Faculty of Engineering; IDA+X Double Maj Prog; ASEI+X Double Maj Prog; MASE+X Double Maj Prog; and students who have taken ENGG1920.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course emphasizes on learning by experiencing. The learning activities include classroom lecturing, group discussion, software practices, and development projects. Students will study existing AI applications and design new applications. Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to
explain the principles of main types of AI technologies
describe the process of developing a typical AI application
analyze and evaluate a given AI application
prepare and organize training data for machine learning models
use a common AI tool to develop basic applications
design and demonstrate a new use case of AI
courses.course_syllabus:
Basic principles of AI – Computational algorithms; basic concepts of machine learning; the roles of data in AI.
Main types of AI technologies – computer vision; natural language processing; knowledge discovery and reasoning; robots and autonomous vehicles.
AI development platforms and tools – Commonly used programming languages; software development environment; online coding platforms and resources.
Python programming in AI – Python programming basics; case study of Python projects; Python libraries for AI.
AI and cloud – Cloud services of AI technologies; data resources on cloud.
Computing hardware for AI – Computational requirement of AI technologies; high-performance computers.
Data collection and preparation – Types of data; publicly available data repository; collection and annotation of data; quality of data; data privacy.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Data Exploration - Statistics in Daily Life
courses.description: This is an introduction to statistical concepts and reasoning with emphasis on applying statistical intuition in daily life. Statistics is the art and science of learning from sample data and making generalizations about populations, which can be applied to different fields in the society, including medical treatment, election, finance, etc. The course aims to introduce the role and use of statistics, and to enhance student's ability of utilizing statistical knowledge in everyday life. Topics include collecting and summarizing data, using and misusing statistics, evaluating the accuracy of estimates from the sample data, and making statistical inferences about populations.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for RMSC,STAT,QFRM,CDAS majors; and students in Data Science or Mathematical Science concentration areas in Natural Sciences Programme.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.academic_org: Dept of Stat and Data Sci
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students are expected to (1) learn about collecting and summarizing the sample data (T1, T3, T4, T5); (2) develop a systematic approach in handling various types of statistical problems (T2, T3, T4, T5); (3) identify the misuse of statistics in everyday life (T2, T3, T4, T5, T6); (4) apply statistical tools to draw conclusions from different fields in the society (T1, T4, T5, T6); (5) enhance teamwork(S1).
T1 Basic concepts in statistics: population, sample, parameter and statistic.
T2 Use and misuse of sample surveys, randomized experiments and observational studies.
T3 Use and misuse of graphical summaries in statistics.
T4 Relationship between Quantitative Variables.
T5 Relationship between Categorical Variables.
T6 Understanding Probability.
S1 Ability to work in team.
courses.course_syllabus: This course targets on applying basic statistical concepts to everyday life. Students will gain a conceptual understanding of statistical methods which can apply to different fields in the society. Topics include: Using and Misusing Statistics, Measurements, Sample Surveys, Randomized Experiments and Observational Studies, Summarizing and Displaying Measurement Data, Bell Shaped Curves, Relationship between Quantitative Variables, Understanding Probability and Hypothesis Testing.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Exploring the Physical World with STEM
courses.description: (UGEB1506 is double-coded with PHYS1004.) The course aims at revealing the fundamental role that physics principles have been playing in the development of science and technology (S&T), which has drastically changed our ways of living and understanding of nature. Successful stories on the evolution of S&T in human history are introduced in the perspectives of STEM, i.e., from the discovery of fundamental Scientific (Physics) (S) principles, to applying the principles to Technological (T) innovations, solving Engineering (E) problems to make the applications viable, and with Mathematics (M) as the essential language that encompasses the whole process. Modern technology is also shown to change the ways of modern scientific investigation and accelerate human understanding of the physical world in an unprecedented speed. Science related social issues are used to help students understand the importance of using science principles and knowledge in making judgements and informed decisions. Lively demonstrations, lab visit, and STEM activities are used in class to (1) illustrate basic physics principles, (2) make physics principles more connected to students’ daily life applications, and (3) better prepare students for explaining science concepts and conducting basic educational STEM activities as an educator, publisher, reporter, and in other S&T related disciplines in the future. Secondary school physics are not required to take this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB1506 is double-coded with PHYS1004.
Not for Physics Majors; and students who have taken PHYS1004.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
Explain and apply some fundamental physics principles in non-technical terms.
Create, plan, and conduct basic STEM education activities related to physics and explain the underlying principles.
Explain and exemplify the interplay between science and technology, especially on how fundamental physics principles have evolved into innovative applications that changed the world, and how the advance in technology has accelerated our understanding of nature.
Recognize and appreciate the generality and beauty of physics principles and be aware of its working in nature, its impacts on technology and daily life.
Recognize and appreciate mathematics as the language of physical sciences and its fundamental role in all forms of engineering.
Analyze scientific information in public media and popular science contexts; and think critically on science related issues.
Make judgements and informed decisions based on science principles and knowledge.
Be motivated to learn about science and technology as a part of life-longed learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Major topics (nos. in […] refer to the references in Section 8):
Motions and Energy: Motion and inertia; Newton’s second law of motion, friction, momentum, applications of these concepts on traffic and road safety; energy and power, and examples including chemical changes in digesting food and explosion; different sources of energy and their environmental impacts [1,2,4,5].
Amazing Fluids: Basic introduction to the concepts of fluids such as density, pressure, viscosity, fluid resistance, diffusion and turbulence; basic principles of flying machines from frisbee to airplane; interactions of fluids with micro-particles, face masks and COVID-19 prevention [1,2,15].
Wonders of Light: Basic geometrical and wave properties of light, reflection, refraction, dispersion, diffraction and interference, and daily life applications; light-atom interactions, emission and absorption spectra, spectrometry and applications; basic principles of laser and its modern applications: optical fibre, laser surgery, optical tweezers, fluorescence imaging; blue LED and applications [1,2,3,9,10,11,12].
Beyond Light: Maxwell’s discovery of electromagnetic waves, electromagnetic spectrum, ionizing and non-ionizing radiations; uses of non-ionizing radiations including communication, temperature measurements, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); applications, hazards, and safety of ionizing radiations.
Ultracold world: Temperature, heat and basic heat transfer mechanisms; change of phases, phase diagram and factors affecting phase changes, change in material properties on cooling, basic concepts on superconductivity and its applications such as magnetic levitation and MRI [1,2,3,5,6,8,9,13,14].
Going Small: Structure of atoms and dual nature of elementary particles, basic quantum phenomena, electrons and electron microscopes, constructing and seeing nanostructures, present and future applications [1,3,4,6,8,9].
Essential skills and concepts taught together with the topics above [4,5,7]:
Educational demonstration experiments and STEM activities for conveying basic physics concepts and the underlying principles of technological applications.
Interpreting and presenting science information in a non-technical way, understanding the degree of confidence of scientific experiments, popularizing science, awareness of the risk of distortion and exaggeration, ethics in conveying science information.
The roles of mathematics in physics and technology are illustrated with exemplars on (1) the importance of precision and accuracy in scientific measurements, (2) how the order of magnitude of physical quantities crucially affect the outcomes of physical phenomena, and (3) how mathematical derivations deliver essential results that go much beyond qualitative understanding.

Students are welcome to give feedbacks to the course teacher at any time in person or through emails.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Exploring Earth and Environmental Sciences

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LAU Yee Wai, 
Dr. LI Kwan Kit Ronald, 
Dr. ZHANG Li

courses.description: (UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001.) The course provides an interdisciplinary study of the Earth Systems, including natural phenomena in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere. The mechanism of these systems, associated dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced and discussed. The course also serves as a platform to understand and critically assess global environmental change, natural hazards, biodiversity loss, and the water-energy-food nexus, and explore potential technological and policy solutions to these problems. These objectives align strongly with the understanding and pursuit of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life Below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land. In addition to attending lectures, students will visit the Jockey Club Museum of Climate Change where it displays the way scientists examine past and current climate and the factors leading to current global temperature change. A geological field excursion will be another highlight of the course to demonstrate the scientific concepts applied to reveal Earth’s tectonic history, evolution and interaction among various spheres. With diverse scientific topics in Earth’s systems, the course shows students how each Earth’s system is interlocking with other spheres and, hence raise the awareness in the importance of sustainability.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB1870 is double-coded with EESC1001
Not for majors in Fac. of Sci., IDA+X Double Maj.Prog., or ASEI+X Double Maj.Prog.; MASE+X Double Maj.Prog. and students who have taken EESC1001 or ESSC1000.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
Experiential Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
Describe and explain how the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere interact and how feedback mechanisms operate among the Earth systems.
Develop an interdisciplinary approach for investigating Earth system dynamics.
Discuss the anthropogenic influences, as well as scientific and technical challenges related to global environmental changes, natural hazards, and the food-water-energy nexus critically.
Recognize the complexity of linkages between environmental pressures and human responses related to contemporary sustainable development challenges, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#14 Life below Water, and SDG#15 Life on Land.
Communicate effectively about Earth system and environmental issues in an appropriate science format (i.e. scientific poster and QnA) through working independently and collaboratively.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lectures
: To provide students basic concepts of different spheres, background information about present environmental phenomena and scientific approaches to study the Earth system
Tutorial:
To guide students critically think about Earth system and related issues to our environment.
Visit:
To show students how professional field works to understand our Earth
Field trip:
To facilitate students observe the environment and interpret and discuss related environmental problems
Note:
Students are expected to attend all lectures, and participate in all tutorials, the visit and the field trip. Meeting with academic advisors can be arranged upon request.
Course Syllabus (English) (Tentative)
The course content will be divided into three parts:
Part I: Geosphere and Cryosphere (Week 1-5)
This component focuses on studying the solid Earth using gravity, electromagnetic and seismic methods. Students will be introduced to the solid physical foundations of the solid Earth, as well as an overview of the structure and composition of the Earth, its materials and constituents, dynamics of its internal and external processes.
Part II: Atmosphere and Climate (Week 7-9)
This compenent covers an integrated introduction to the climate system and the dynamics and chemistry of the atmosphere. Students will learn to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards, and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence.
Part III: Ecosystem Interactions (Week 10-12)
This compenent covers the interactions of the terrestrial and marine biosphere with the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere. Students will be introduced to the physical and chemical processes governing the exchange of energy and matter between the biosphere and the environment, addressing related issues such as habitat decline, biodiversity loss, and environmental pollution.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Mind, Brain and AI
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamentals and contemporary developments of artificial intelligence (AI) as well as brain research and discusses the philosophical issues arising from these rapidly developing research fields. Topics include major approaches of AI, the Turing test, Searle and Dreyfus’ critique of AI; fundamentals of neuroscience, techniques of brain imaging, the mapping of brain functions; the mind-brain relation, philosophical theories of mind and the nature of mental phenomena like consciousness and free will. The aim is to help students to reflect on the potentials and limits of AI and brain research and to achieve a deeper understanding of ourselves as human beings.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken PHIL4333.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Recognize the latest developments of computer technology and brain research.
Identify and discuss the central issues of the philosophy of AI and mind.
Critically analyze problems arising in our technological age.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Physics in Movies: Science or Fiction?
courses.description: The course aims at providing a short introduction to many popular physics ideas used in movies. There are many modern physics ideas that have captured the imagination of people, and many popular science fiction movies love to use these ideas for artistic or plot purposes. In this course, we will take a look at how these physics ideas are portrayed in selected movies, and have a discussion on how much of these are based on real science, or just pure fiction. The course also explores from a broader perspective how the advances in science and technology inspire the creation of art and pop culture, and how these derived ideas inspire generations of young people to unravel the mysteries of nature. Topics covered may include extraterrestrial civilization (Fermi paradox, SETI), spacetime travel, black holes, pulsars, space exploration, orbital dynamics, particle physics, antimatter, nuclear fusion/fission, quantum mechanics, superconductors, etc. Sometimes real physical phenomena can be even more bizarre than in movies!
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for Physics Majors;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
Explain
some fundamental physics principles in non-technical terms.
Reflect and exemplify the depiction of science (physics) in popular media, examine how realistic they are, and evaluate the tradeoff between artistic choice and accuracy.
Recognize and
appreciate
the generality and beauty of physics principles and be aware of its working in nature, and its impacts on technology and daily life.
Recognize and appreciate
the artistic value of accurately depicting physics in the media.
Analyze
scientific information in public media and popular science contexts; and think critically about science-related issues.
Make
judgements and informed decisions based on scientific principles and knowledge.
Recognize
and
examine
a broadened intellectual perspective on nature, science and technology by
connecting
some physics concepts seen in movies to reality.
Be motivated to learn about science and technology as a part of life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will have a different physics concept every week.
Tentative themes and the associated movie lists are listed below for each week.
The course starts with a discussion of relativity and space travel, which focuses mostly on macroscopic scale topics in astronomy and astrophysics. The second half starts a discussion with quantum mechanics, which focuses on the microscopic world with topics in particle physics and new states of matter. Students can thus gain a big picture of modern physics by connecting physical phenomena that emerged at different scales.
Time travels, time dilations, Relativity (Interstellar, Avengers)
How does the discovery of relativity result in the concept of “Spacetime”? What is the meaning of a relative time and space, and how can we time travel?
Black holes and the 2017 and 2020 Nobel physics prizes (Interstellar)
What are black holes? How were they made? Where can we find them? What happens when we are near the black holes?
Pulsars, SETI (Contact)
What happens when stars die? What are pulsars? What are we doing to search for extraterrestrial intelligence?
Orbital Dynamics, space exploration (Martian, Gravity)
What are things that we need to consider if we want to colonize the solar system, or maybe beyond?
3-Body problem and Fermi Paradox (3 Body)
Why 3-body problem is not solvable? What is the logic behind the Fermi paradox?
Asteroids and extinction events (Don’t look up)
How real is the danger of asteroid impacts? How did the dinosaurs go extinct?
Quantum mechanics (Antman 1/2)
Why is the bizarre world of quantum mechanics?
Anti-matter, particle colliders (Angels and Demons)
What are the fundamental particles of nature? How are they useful to us? How do we study them?
Ghost particles, neutrinos (2012, ghostbusters)
What are neutrinos (aka the ghost particles)?
Nuclear fusion, fission (Oppenheimer)
What is the physics of nuclear weapons?
Superconductors (Avatar)
What are superconductors and their properties? Are they really “unobtainium”? How could they reshape our society in the future, if the room temperature superconductors are developed?

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Nature Conservation in Hong Kong
courses.description: (UGEB2113 is double-coded with GRMD2403.)  This course aims at providing students with an overall view on nature conservation in general and Hong Kong in particular. It will examine the history and development of nature conservation in Hong Kong including legislation, designation and management of the protected areas. Specifically, country, marine parks and geopark are developed to protected terrestrial and marine habitats as well as the associated wildlife, and geodiversity, respectively. Threats and problems facing existing protected areas will be discussed. Nature conservation will be addressed through lectures, field trips and students’ projects. It will also introduce concepts and principles of nature conservation in the local and global context, including climate change, ecosystem services, geo-conservation and the global conservation efforts such as the World Summit and Convention of Biodiversity. The course helps students look at nature conservation from the perspective of sustainable development, incorporating the environmental, social and economic dimensions of development, focusing on SDG Goals 14 and 15 in particular. Both SDGs are directly linked to nature conservation efforts, focusing on preserving natural resources, ecosystems, and biodiversity, which are vital for the health of our planet, ensuring sustainable fishing/forest management practices for the benefit of communities.

courses.course_syllabus:
Course themes
Part 1.
Nature Conservation
Key concepts - What is nature? Why nature conservation? Nature conservation and Hong Kong
Man and the environment - Relationship between human and nature, Environmental movement
Nature conservation in Hong Kong - History, Protected areas in Hong Kong, Implications and lessons learnt
Protecting marine and terrestrial ecosystems is related to SDG14 (life below water) and SDG15 (life on land)
Part 2.
Protected area I: Country park
Design - From conservation to sustainable development, Park design and infrastructure, land use and enclaves
Recreation impact and management - Facilities and services, Patterns of recreational use of country parks, Visitor management
Threats and Challenges - Threats to nature conservation, Zoning and park design, Onsite and offsite management
Afforestation - Afforestation and plantation, Woodland conservation
Country Park plays an important role in advancing several SDGs (3, 6, 11,15) by conserving natural ecosystems and promoting sustainable resource use
Part 3.
Protected area II: Marine park
Conservation of marine habitats/species
Management of marine habitats
Conservating marine environments through marine park contributes to the well-being of both marine life (SDG14) and human communities (SDG3)
Part 4.
Protected area III: Geopark
Geo-conservation in Hong Kong
Social and economic benefits
UNESCO Global Geoparks promote sustainable local economic growth through sustainable tourism (SDG8)
Part 5.
Conservation policy
Development pressure and development control
Administrative options
Nature conservation in the 21st century
Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan of Hong Kong
Bottom-up approach to nature conservation
The role of green groups, local people and other stakeholders

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Climate, Energy and Life

meetings.instructor:
Professor LI Jianfeng, 
Professor XU Yuan

Professor LI Jianfeng, 
Professor XU Yuan

Professor LI Jianfeng, 
Professor XU Yuan

Professor LI Jianfeng, 
Professor XU Yuan

courses.description: Climate change is a subject of great interest to all concerned about the future of mankind. However, very few people realize that climate has always been changing since the formation of the Earth. Even fewer people realize that the living things in their totality exert a significant influence in shaping the evolution of the climate itself. One striking feature of the current climate change is that it has arisen from the action of one single species Homo sapiens, owing to its ability to master the use of an enormous amount of energy.This course presents the story of the Earth's atmosphere since its inception up to the current time, illustrating the close interactions between the physical world and the living world. Observations about the life phenomenon are discussed, including the role of energy in the sustenance of life, individually and collectively. The changing climate has provided the context for the development of life on Earth, in terms of dispersion and diversity. The glacial periods have also shaped the habits and character of human beings. The arrival of the recent warm interglacial period facilitated the emergence of agriculture, enabling human beings to capture and utilize more energy in their life cycles. It brought about major changes to human beings' way of life as well as significant disruptions to the delicate balance in nature. Major turning points in history such as the emergence of civilizations, the conflict between nomads and pastoralists, wars and maritime colonialism are discussed in the climate context. Industrial revolution and modern consumerism are discussed in terms of their energy consumption and the associated emission of greenhouse gases, which has given rise to the current man-made climate change. Other aspects of this enormous use of energy are discussed, including urbanization, the attrition of the self and human beings' increasing detachment from nature. Latest projections of the climate in the 21st century and the potential consequences are presented. How the human world would deal with the potential of hazardous climate change will be explored, including the particular problems faced by China as it is about to develop further. It would be a time to reflect on the core human values and how they are to be expressed in the new low-energy world.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to develop a general and comprehensive understanding of the "climate change" subject from a multi-disciplinary perspective and to appreciate that climate is the result of the intimate interactions between the physical world and the living world. The course will discuss climate change from multiple perspectives of several physical and social sciences such as climatology, geography, geology, biology, history, and cultural and political studies. Therefore, students will not only gain basic knowledge of geophysical concepts and rules of climate, energy, and life, but also learn how climate change arises from the complex interactions between the physical environment and human society in geological and historical times. They will also learn to realize the phenomenal impacts of consumerism with its attendant energy expenditure, in the last half century on the Earth's climate. As concerned world citizens, students will need to be equipped with these capabilities and knowledge in order to better understand the emerging challenges posed by global warming and adopt mitigation measures for sustainable development.
courses.course_syllabus:
A. The natural world:
This component covers the co-evolution of the physical world and the living world from the inception of the Earth up the point where agriculture emerged. The concept of the Earth’s atmosphere as the collective breath of life on Earth will be developed. In that process, the fundamental characteristics of life as an energy phenomenon will be discussed, to bring out ideas about energy flow and various cycles in nature. How the glacial periods and associated habitat changes shape the habits and character of human beings will be discussed.
Related course topics: 1. Introduction, atmosphere and climate; 2. Climate change, roles of greenhouse gases, aerosols and other agents in climate change;
B. The world with agriculture:
This component examines the emergence of agriculture during the latest interglacial warm period and what happened afterwards as human beings have more energy at its disposal. The climate and geography of civilization emergence in association with agriculture are discussed. The subsequent changed way of life and attendant problems are examined, with a view to prompting students to re-evaluate the role of "civilization" in life. The broad course of human history, especially the major turning points, in the time scale of thousands of years will be discussed in the context of climate and its variability.
Related course topics: 3. Monsoon climate, Mediterranean climate, Semi-arid climate, floodplain and watershed; 4. and 5. Co-evolution of the physical world and the living world, agriculture and animal husbandry (I) (II)
C. The burning world:
This component places its focus on the post-industrial revolution period in which human beings has mastered the use of even more energy. The link between the burning of fossil fuel to rapid changes in the atmospheric composition and the climate will be described. Other consequential impacts will be discussed, such as changes in the natural world and more subtly those in the human society. The inter-connection among energy, technology, urbanization, consumerism and climate change will be explored.
Related course topics: 6. Oil and war; 7. Coal and industrial revolution
D. The future:
The imminent hazardous climate change in the 21st century and choices available to human beings as a species will be discussed. Various countries will be examined, to illustrate the complexity of the issues involved and the very fundamental nature of the decisions to be made.
Related course topics: 8. Global climate governance and carbon neutrality; 9. Carbon neutrality in individual countries; 10. Energy and climate geopolitics in 2050 and the rise and fall of economies

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Environmental Crises – China and the World

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course will provide an introduction of China’s major environmental crises at local, regional, national and global scales and at different stages of development. It covers topics from air pollution (both indoor and outdoor), water shortage (due to the lack of water resources and water pollution), soil pollution, waste management, desertification & deforestation, energy transition and greenhouse gas emissions, as well as climate change. The foci will not only cover the causes and seriousness of the crises from the perspectives of science, technology, society and governance, but also solutions and emerging norms related to the topics. The course endeavors to inspire students to reflect on their own communities and how to approach sustainable development goals at a variety of scales.Multiple of the United Nations’ 17 Sustainable Development Goals are closely relevant to the lectures, including (7) Affordable and Clean Energy, (6) Clean Water and Sanitation, (13) Climate Action, (12) Responsible Consumption and Production, (9) Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, and (17) Partnerships for the Goals. This course uses an interdisciplinary approach to lead students through relevant key topics. Students from most departments in natural sciences, engineering, social sciences, public health, and business management will be able to find connections between these topics and their own disciplines. The approach will provide students chances to independently think about the problems beyond any discipline. Because environmental problems are frequently reflected in social and individual daily lives, the course will make students more informed in the increasingly globalizing society for their better contribution to more sustainable development.

courses.description: Climate change, sea level rise, deforestation, forest fire, severe typhoon, glacier melt, agricultural loss, overpopulation, etc. are terms that you might have heard of. And they are also real and hot crises affecting the sustainability of human beings. How do we know these are all happening? In fact, our earth is being overseen from space every day. One good example is Google Earth that takes us any part of the globe anytime and anywhere using fingertips. Have you wondered where do these images come from? How these images are captured? How can images be used to understand the happening on our earth? Most of these images are captured by giant machines hovering in space known as satellites. “Remote sensing” is the process to collect images from the space or in the air, which is one of the key tools in the regime of spatial information technology. Important information are extracted from these images to gain better understanding of status quo and be more sustainable and responsible to our home – Earth.This course allows students to acquire basic knowledge of remote sensing and to understand how the technology is used to the study and monitor of our earth. The course is divided into two parts. The first part elucidates the basic concept of remote sensing as well as the skills in extracting information from images. The second part unveils the applications of remote sensing images to crucial sustainability issues such as urban development, agriculture, forest management, natural disaster, climate change, etc. These applications connect with three Sustainable Development Goals including #11 (sustainable cities and community), #13 (climate action) and #15 (life on land) set by the United Nations in 2015. Loads of remotely-sensed images are used to illustrate the natural process and human activities that alter the earth surface and to explore the issue of sustainability. Together with hands-on work in tutorials and interactive class activity, students would be aware of how this novel technology is exploring the future of human beings.

SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I. Remote Sensing: Beyond the Naked Eyes
1. Remote Sensing: Connection Between Earth and Us
遙感：我們與地球的連線
2. From Image to Information: Searching for Meaning
從影像到信息：尋覓影像中意義
3. Remotely-sensed Images: Getting to Know
遙感影像：慢慢認識
4. Aerial Photography: Flying in the Sky
航空攝影：在天上飛
5. Satellite: Sensing from Space
衛星：太空中感應
6. The Thinking Machine: The Best Image Assistant
電腦：最佳影像助理
Part II. Remote sensing applications and SDGs
7. Land Use and Cover: Revealing Our Valuable Earth Resource
土地利用和覆蓋：揭示我們寶貴的地球資源
8. Urban: Tracing the Rapid Transformations of Civilizations
城市：追踪急速轉變中的文明
9. Agriculture and Forest: Sustaining the Green Resources
農業和森林：可持續的綠色資源
10. Natural Disaster: Witnessing and Chasing the Rage of Earth
自然災難：見證及追蹤地球的憤怒
11. Mysterious Ocean: Monitoring the Secret of the Deep Blue
神秘的海洋：監視深藍色的秘密
12. Global Climate Change: Threats of Today and Tomorrow
全球氣候變化：今天和明天的威脅
13. GIS: Merging Spatial Data for Sustainable Home
地理資訊系統： 合併空間數據以建設可持續家園

courses.description: Music is an art and a science. Questions like “how do we perceive music,” “how does music arouse emotions in us,” “can artificial intelligence (AI) perceive music like us,” “how can AI recognize emotions expressed in music,” “can AI arouse emotions in us through music” are all scientific in nature. This interdisciplinary course invites students to analyse and appreciate music from two scientific perspectives, namely, psychology and AI. It begins with musical elements, which are the basic building blocks of music, from the viewpoint of both music perception and production. The science behind those elements is explored with an emphasis on how they evoke emotions. We then examine the basic concepts of AI and its capability of producing music applications including music emotion recognition and automatic music composition. Along with interactive lectures, students will engage in hands-on experiences and class discussions that culminate towards various music-related AI projects. No prior knowledge in music or programming is required.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Music Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
Understand the concepts of music fundamentals from the scientific perspective.
Explain how one perceives music via the empirical studies in music psychology and understand the scientific methods employed in those studies.
Explain how computers can use AI to learn from data, identify patterns and make decisions with minimal human intervention.
Demonstrate the competency in designing and implementing music applications with the technology of AI.
Appraise and evaluate the impact of AI on music listeners, music industry and the society.
Reflect in depth about critical similarities, differences, and intersections between how we and AI hear music so as to demonstrate how music is both an art and a science.
courses.course_syllabus:
How do we hear music?
How do we hear sound and music?
Physical properties of sound
Basic concepts of music elements and the science behind
How do we make sense of music?
Psychoacoustic effects of organised sound
Scientific theories of music and emotion
How do we create musical experiences that arouse emotions?
Emotion through musical performance: Empirical studies
Emotion through musical composition: A sound project with the use of a software program
How does AI hear music?
How do computers process music signals?
Mathematical representation of music signals
Basic concepts of signal processing
How do computers make sense of music?
Basic concepts of artificial intelligence, with the focus on machine learning.
Automated music data analysis: A machine learning project with the use of a drag-and-drop development app
How do computers recognize and generate music emotions?
Basic concepts of affective computing
Music emotion recognition: A machine learning project with the use of a drag-and-drop development app
The connections between the above two topics will be highlighted throughout the course. Understanding how we hear music can helps us develop AI systems to hear music like us. On the other hand, modelling how we hear, perform and compose music in computers with AI can provide a point of reference of how we perform those tasks.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: China's Mega-Projects in the New Millennium
courses.description: As the most populous country in the world, China is confronted by the problems of overpopulation, water scarcity, energy shortage, desertification, drought, floods, pollution, and loss of biodiversity. Since 1978 the economy has grown rapidly and as of to date, it has become a rising economic power of the world. However, the environmental and ecological problems have reached a point whereby sustainable growth is jeopardized. To solve the problems of limited resource per capita, as well as encourage economic development, China has implemented and planned for a series of mega projects of far-reaching repercussions, the scale of which is unmatched in the history of mankind. They range from multi-purpose water conservancy projects to renewable energy projects and inter-provincial railway construction. These projects have been conceived for decades yet highly controversial and expensive to build. Meanwhile, China has made a commitment that it will shoulder the responsibility of implementing the 2030 development agenda (17 Sustainable Development Goals, SDGs), and seek solidarity and cooperation to constantly push the cause of global development. This course gives students a general background of these mega-projects, the problems they attempt to resolve, benefits, as well as how these projects trying to meet the SDGs (especially the SDGs 6, 7 and 13 of water scarcity, affordable clean energy and climate actions, respectively), and the potential collaborations with other countries contributing to human well-being. After taking this course, students should have a comprehensive understanding about the occurrence, nature and sustainable solutions of the various environmental problems China is facing.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #6 Clean Water and Sanitation
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #17 Partnerships for the Goals
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course focuses on implications of the mega projects committed by
China
instead of their technical aspects. The course content is meant to be comprehensive, integrated and relevant in some way to students' own discip1ir.e of study. After taking this course, students are expected to have a comprehensive understanding about the latest developments in
China
. Specifically, the expected learning outcomes shall include:
1. Understanding the environmental crisis of
China
and possible sustainable solutions;
2. Learning how to think critically in general, and understanding complex socioeconomic and environmental issues in particular;
3. Understanding the responses to new challenges in the 21st century with respect to sustainable development goals using
China
as an example; and
4. Update of useful knowledge about
China
to broaden/enhance students' job opportunities and employability.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 
Resources, population and development challenges of China
2. 
China’s Mega-projects for water scarcity:
2. 1
South-North Water Transfer Project: Can water from afar quench the thirst of north China?
2. 2
National Ecological Restoration Projects: How to solve water crisis naturally and sustainably?
2. 3
Combating water pollution: A goal too far?
3. 
China’s Mega-projects for affordable clean energy and climate actions
3. 1
The Three Gorges Dam Project: A multi-purpose water conservancy project or a damned project?
3. 2
The West-East Gas Pipeline Project: Does Hong Kong get involved in the project that aims to improve air quality and reduce CO2 emission?
3. 3
The West-East Electricity Transmission Project: What are the reasons and impacts for the giant transmission grid?
3. 4
Cleaning up air pollution: Can China Get to ‘Olympic Blue’?
4. 
Other Mega-projects in China
4. 1
Qinghai-Tibetan Railway: Will this heavenly railway help develop China’s great west?
4. 2
High-speed rail in China: should be faster or slower?

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Resource Issues in the Age of Globalization
courses.description: Globalization processes have been affecting every nook and corner of the world. We are all fascinated by the mushrooming of transnational companies; the increasing cross-boundary flows of resources as well as the increasing competition among places and cities. Resource becomes a keen issue due to the growth of population, trade and economy in the age of globalization. Good management of resources will thus be both global and local concerns. In this regard and with the advent of the global agenda 2030, there is increasing enthusiasm in addressing the most pressing and challenging issues that the world is facing today, and these are Globalization and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).This course will thus focus on the interaction of man and environment in a geographical context with special reference to a selection of relevant SDGs. By adopting different perspectives, a variety of resource issues ranging from natural resources to economic and human resources will be examined. The course will be divided into two parts. The first part will be the discussion of basic concepts of globalization and resource issues in the society that are related to selected SDGs. The second part will be issue-based analyses of different resource issues that affect lives in modern societies and that could make a difference in the pursuit of the SDGs particularly in this age of globalization. Various cases in the real world will be analyzed. This course will help students to broaden their views on the SDGs and understand the importance and implications of resource issues in both developing and developed countries.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #2 Zero Hunger
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
SDG-GE #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through a variety of teaching and learning activities, including lectures, video shows, forum and group discussion on current issues, the student will be able to:
understand the basic concepts of resource issues and globalization
develop analytical and critical thinking capabilities through the discussion of various case studies and current issues
students will be able to develop self-awareness and reflect their roles in local communities and at the international context
enhance the skills necessary for interpreting relevant planning and management of resources in the society

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Environmental Challenges in Hong Kong
courses.description: Hong Kong is fraught with many environmental challenges nowadays, ranging from environmental pollution to nature conservation. These challenges have brought about conflicts between different camps and caused significant difficulties in governance. This course will guide students to critically analyze these environmental challenges through a theoretical framework built upon the latest understanding of the politics of policy making and considerations in ethics, technology and economics. The course will demonstrate the use of the theoretical framework through the analysis of real Hong Kong cases, field trips, video watching and assignments. Through these various learning activities, students are expected to acquire the relevant knowledge and develop skills in critical analysis, data collection, field observation and capability in policy evaluation and problem solving.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes: The course will provide a comprehensive introduction to major environmental problems in Hong Kong. Students will gain the basic scientific knowledge of these issues and master a theoretical framework for analyzing these problems built upon the science of pollution and the dynamics and complexity of environmental governance. Furthermore, students will also learn the techniques to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of different solutions. All these will make our students environmentally conscious and responsible citizens locally and globally.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is made up of four modules as follows:
Module 1: Environmental challenges of Hong Kong (1 week)
· Nature and origin of environmental problems
· Environmental awareness and public aspirations
· Environmental governance – responsible government agencies and policy making processes
· Different stakeholders – their values, beliefs and positions
Module 2: Theoretical framework for analyzing environmental challenges (1 week)
· Policy cycle
· Key considerations: technology, impacts, economics, politics
· Science, value, belief, justice
· Dynamics among key stakeholders
Module 3: Application of the conceptual framework, to analyze the latest environmental challenges under the categories: (8 weeks)
· Pollution problems, such as air, water, noise and waste management
· Nature and biodiversity conservation, and related conflicts between development and conservation
· Development planning including the use of EIA and planning control; and/or
· Plus any environmental issues which may arise from time to time
Module 4: Solutions to Environmental Challenges (2 weeks)
· Windows of opportunity for intervention
· Instruments: policy, regulation, planning and incentives
· Considerations and methods in policy evaluation
· Implementation and enforcement

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Natural Hazards
courses.description: What are the major natural hazards and why do they occur around the world? What places are most vulnerable to multiple hazards? What are the disasters caused by a hazard and how do people respond? How to manage various types of natural hazards which affect the sustainability of urban and rural development? Students will find enormous interest in seeking answers to these questions. This course examines the physical and human dimensions of natural hazards such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis, landslides, tropical cyclones, floods and droughts. Through a variety of teaching and learning activities, this course will help students understand major natural hazards from a regional perspective, in terms of their causes, location and distribution, human responses to prepare, prevent and mitigate their impacts on sustainable development.Effective management and mitigation of natural hazards are essential for building safe, resilient, and sustainable cities (SDG11) and for combating and adapting to climate change (SDG13). This course provides students with real-life examples that help students understand the relevant economic, social and environmental issues caused by natural hazards. The knowledge empowers students to evaluate the effectiveness of various mitigation measures to minimise the impact on people, contributing to more resilient and sustainable societies. Study of the interaction between society and natural hazards will help students better understand the man-environment relationship. An issue-based approach from a topical perspective is adopted to address a wide variety of geological, meteorological, and hydrological hazards. The importance of geographical regions in understanding natural hazards and their socio-economic impacts is highlighted throughout the course. Case studies of occurrences and natural hazard management in Hong Kong and other parts of the world are emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Workshop
courses.course_syllabus:
PART 1 Introduction: Is the world becoming more and more dangerous?
GEOHAZARDS MANAGEMENT
Geohazard management is essential for achieving SDG11 as it involves identifying, assessing and mitigating risks associated with geological hazards such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis and landslides. Geohazard management is closely linked to SDG13 because climate change can increase the frequency and intensity of geohazards.
Part I Introduction
– Is the world becoming more and more dangerous?
Earthquake
– What are earthquakes? Why and where do earthquakes occur? How to assess earthquakes and how about the impact?
Volcanic eruptions
– Why do volcanoes erupt? Where can we find volcanoes? What are the hazard types? How to assess volcanic eruptions and how about its impact?
Tsunami
– What is a tsunami? Why tsunami occurs? Where are the sources of tsunami? How to assess and mitigate its impact? Is Hong Kong at risk?
Landslide
– What is a landslide? How to classify mass movements? How to identify the key movement types? What are “natural terrain landslides” in Hong Kong?
PART 2 Introduction: Atmosphere and hazardous weather systems
Hydro-meteorological hazard management helps in achieving SDG11 and SDG13 by addressing risks associated with extreme weather-related hazards such as storms, floods and droughts, that may cause loss of life, injury or other health impacts, property damage, loss of livelihoods and services, social and economic disruption, or environmental damage.
Part 2 Introduction
– Atmospheric and hazardous weather systems
METEOROLOGICAL HAZARD MANAGEMENT
Tropical cyclone
– What is a tropical cyclone? How does a tropical cyclone form? What are the impacts? How to get prepared?
HYDROLOGICAL HAZARD MANAGEMENT
Flood
– What is a flood? What are the main types of floods? How to assess flood risk? How to mitigate floods?

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Natural Wonders of the World
courses.description: For many of us, the natural wonders of our planet are well known, for example, Antarctica, the Amazon Forests, the Great Barrier Reef and the Grand Canyon. Yet, few people really understand their formation and presence. This course introduces students to the concepts and processes of environmental change, such as climate change, land use change, desertification, and habitat loss.The course adopts a scientific approach to help students understand the processes of environmental change behind some of the planet’s famous natural landscapes, landforms and natural phenomena. These shall include the natural processes (geological, atmospheric, hydrological and ecological) and anthropogenic processes (land use change, fossil fuel combustion and infrastructure development). The course is designed around the four themes of: (i) the processes and patterns of landscape formation; (ii) the combination of natural and human-induced environmental change; (iii) benefits of natural wonders to human beings; and (iv) the methods and challenges of protecting natural wonders.This course will cover at least three Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), namely SDG13 Climate Action, SDG14 Life Below Water, and SDG15 Life On Land. The impact of climate change on various natural wonders and related human well-being will be examined, along with possible ways to mitigate and adapt to climate change. Also, the influence of human activities on terrestrial and marine ecosystems, as well as possible options for their sustainable management will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix

SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Understanding Nature – the Basic Elements
2. Tropical Rainforests: Valuable but Highly Exploited by Humans
3. Great Barrier Reef: Declining Rainforest of the Sea
4. Deserts: Coping with Desertification
5. Wetlands: Are They Wastelands?
6. Polar Regions: Climate Change Hotspots

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: From Genes to Life
courses.description: Gene is the fundamental unit of inheritance. After the completion of Human Genome Project, scientists have already unraveled some of the mysteries of how genes manipulate our life. Biotechnology, the use of living organisms to make products, has already led to the new industrial revolution, which creates hundreds of thousand jobs and tens of billion dollars revenue in the United States. This course aims to introduce students some fundamental knowledge of how genes determine and control our appearance and behaviour. Recent discoveries of some genes in inheritable diseases (e.g. cancer, Alzheimer's disease, Huntington's disease, etc.), aging and death will be addressed. Successful examples of using biotechnology to improve our medicinal, agricultural and environmental practices will be introduced. Some ethical, legal and social issues generated from genetic research and biotechnology will also be discussed. This course is particularly suitable to those students who are not life science majors but want to understand more on the recent research on human genome and biotechnology, and their impacts on our future worlds.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences, BMEG Majors and NSCI Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
To recognize different intellectual and practical aspects in genetics and biotechnology
To distinguish facts and fallacies of some genetic and biotechnology issues, which appear on mass media
To demonstrate ability to make informed decisions in some controversies in genetics and biotechnology
To appraise the pros and cons of applying biotechnology to human life problems
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is basically composed of
FOUR
modules:
I. THE BASICS
Biology, Facts, and the Scientific Method
Biology is the study of life. The facts in biology are really attempts to state our current understanding of the natural world around us, based on observations that we make and experiments that we do. Biology is rich with examples of facts that were once widely held but have since been superseded as biologists have tramped on to a better understanding of the phenomena those facts attempted to explain. Biologists, as well as other scientists, have made new and better information available with a systematic approach called the scientific method. In this lesson, brief history of the emergence of modern biology will be introduced. Renowned scientists and how they have contributed to the discovery of cell and DNA using the scientific method are introduced, so that the
students can get a sense of what the scientific endeavour is like.
Cell: A Basic Unit of Life
Cell is the basic unit of living organisms. Cells are not static but are dynamic in nature. They have the capacity to grow, to response to stimuli, to adapt to environmental changes, to become differentiated and specialized, and most importantly, they can duplicate themselves exactly by divisions. Nearly all the genetic information needed to direct these activities are contained within the chemical
deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
inside the nucleus. During this lecture, some structural, functional and genetic characteristics of a living cell will be introduced.
The Central Dogma of Directional Flow of Genetic Information
DNA from all organisms is made up of the same chemical and physical components. The DNA sequence is the particular side-by-side arrangement of bases along the DNA strand. This order spells out the exact instructions required to create a particular organism with its own unique traits. The
genome
is an organism's complete set of DNA, and the DNA in the human genome is arranged into 24 distinct
chromosomes.
Each chromosome contains many genes, the basic physical and functional units of heredity.
Genes
are specific sequences of bases that encode instructions on how to make proteins. Although genes get a lot of attention, it is the
proteins
that perform most life functions and even make up the majority of cellular structures. In this lesson, the central dogma of directional flow of genetic information will be addressed, which provides the background knowledge for the following lectures.
The Book of Life
The
Human Genome Project (HGP)
is an international research programme, involving more than 2000 scientists at 20 institutions in 6 countries, to characterize the genomes of humans and other organisms, to develop novel technologies for achieving the goals, and to address the ethical, legal and social impacts of this new information. Although the possibility of sequencing human genome was first discussed in the mid-1980s, the project was only officially started in 1990. After a 13-year work, which is 2 years shorter than it was initially expected, the finalized sequence of the human genome, with 99.99% accuracy, was publicly announced on
14 April, 2003
. Some of the novel insights and interesting findings about the human genome will be addressed in this lecture.
II. ETHICAL, LEGAL AND SOCIAL ISSUES
A
coin has two sides. Although human genome research and biotechnology improve our living quality, they also introduce us some ethical, legal and social problems that greatly attract public attentions and worldwide debates. Some of these foreseeable issues will be discussed, including:
Privacy, confidentiality and fairness in the use of genetic information
Who should have access to personal genetic information, e.g. employers, courts, schools, government agencies, etc.? How will it be used?
Commercialization of genetic information and its products
Should the genetic information donors or the commercial companies own the property rights of the developed products?
Psychological impact, stigmatization, and discrimination
How does personal genetic information affect self-identity and society's perceptions?
Uncertainties associated with gene tests for susceptibilities and complex conditions
Should testing be performed when no treatment is available? Should children be tested for susceptibility to adult-onset diseases?
Health and environmental issues
Are genetically modified (GM) foods and other products safe for human and the environment? How will these technologies affect developing nations' dependence on industrialized nations?
III. GENES, HEALTH, AND DISEASES
Modern genetics has had a profound impact on medicine. Although connections between certain diseases and inheritance were made centuries ago, only during the past decades that geneticists become understood the metabolic basis of several hundred inherited disorders. Detective genes that result in the inherited disorders have been isolated. The genes in normal individuals are called wild-type genes; those with defects that result in the synthesis of nonfunctional products are called mutant genes. They result in abnormal or mutant conditions. These detects in mutant genes are called mutations. In this lecture, some of the better-characterized genetic diseases will be introduced, and the connections between gene mutations and inheritable diseases will be addressed:
What Causes Cancer? How Cancer Arises?
Cancer is one of the leading causes of mortality in our society. Incidence and development of cancer is affected by both heritable gene mutations and environment (including our living lifestyles). Recent studies have shown that cancer is a result of unnecessary cell divisions and resistance to proper cell death. Although gene mutations cannot be prohibited, improving our living quality can markedly reduce the incidence of cancer. Recent knowledge on the causes and development of cancer will be introduced, and some preventive living practices and the recent and prosperous future curative methods will also be discussed during the lesson.
Why Do We Age?
Aging is the chronological process of an individual's life along a time axis, and senescence is the deterioration process associated with aging. Aging cannot be halted but senescence can be slowed down. Several theories accounting for the significance of individual's aging to the population will be introduced in this lesson. Moreover, some classical studies showing causes of senescence and corresponding ways to slow down the process will also be discussed. Results of these studies have already paved the route of development a number of so called "anti-aging" nutraceuticals or food supplements in our market. Finally, a genetic disease called Werner Syndrome, which is caused by the mutations of
WRN
gene and pre-mature senescence, will also be addressed.
IV. BIOTECHNOLOGY AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY IN DAILY LIVINGS
Biotechnology for Improving Our Quality of Life
Nowadays, researchers can cut apart the genome to figure out what the individual parts do. They can make changes to a gene and replace one gene with another. This "cutting and pasting" is called genetic engineering, which is the heart of a whole new industry called
biotechnology
, the use of living things to make products. While many biotechnology creations are still in the experimental stage, a number of them are already on the market. During the lecture, some of the successful examples of using biotechnology to improve our medicinal and agricultural practices will be introduced, e.g. replacement of genes for repairing the genetic defects, duplication of organisms as donors of tissues and organs for transplantation, engineering of some crops to make them more resistant to insects and diseases, creation of new crops with bigger harvest or containing more proteins so that they are more nutritious, etc.
Molecular Biology for Finding the Truth
Court cases hinge on scientific evidence, and forensic science serves as an interface between law and science. Instead of depending solely on the smudged fingerprints left at the scene of a crime, because of the advancement of molecular biology, investigators could now look at a new kind of "fingerprints" called DNA fingerprints, which is the unique signature found in each person's genetic makeup. This DNA-fingerprinting technology, which has been regarded as a revolutionary tool in forensic science, has already helped a number of court cases to condemn the guilty or to exonerate the innocent. In this lecture, the theory and procedures in preparing the DNA fingerprints and its analysis will be introduced. Some of the best-known cases involving DNA evidence will also be considered, as an illustration of the value and vulnerability of using DNA as evidence.
