courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: From Sky to Earth: A Natural Tale of the Greater Bay Area
courses.description: The Earth is an intricate and fragile system. Slight differences in the terrain of neighbouring areas on the Earth can lead to variations in climate, geology, and marine resources. The Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA) is located in the southern coastal area of China and has a subtropical climate influenced by the East Asian Monsoon. Two cities of the GBA, Hong Kong and Shenzhen, are geographically neighbours on the eastern side of the Pearl River estuary. Still, the interaction of oceanic, geologic, and atmospheric systems has shaped their local weather patterns and influenced the availability and distribution of natural resources.This course highlights the geophysics, macroclimate, and marine science of the GBA and the microclimate in Hong Kong’s and Shenzhen’s areas. It aims to engage students in exploring the interconnectedness of the Earth and the sky through interdisciplinary subjects, thereby reflecting on human responsibilities to the natural environment, including the conservation of terrestrial ecosystems and the sustainable use of marine resources. The topics to be covered include the physics of meteorology, the principles of geology, astronomical relevance to climate, human influence on long-term climate, and natural disasters. Additionally, the course includes visiting meteorological institutions, geoparks, and high-tech marine companies.

Not for Environmental Science (ENSC) and Earth and Environmental Sciences (EESC) Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix

SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land

Lecture
Project

Visit
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will:
Gain foundational knowledge of meteorology and geophysics.
Be able to apply theoretical knowledge to explain real-world situations, particularly the weather patterns and geological phenomena in GBA.
Develop critical thinking through analysis of the influence of meteorological and geological processes.
Cultivate an awareness of human and natural impacts on global climate change and environmental concerns, including sustainable use of marine and terrestrial resources, informed by direct engagement with relevant institutions and projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
An Overview (2 hours)
Major concepts:
Interplay of natural systems
Topics:
How does the interaction of natural systems, including oceanic, geologic, and atmospheric processes occur?
What is the interaction in the GBA?
The Sky (10 hours)
Major concepts:
Relevance of astronomy to climate and ocean
Basic principles of meteorology
Topics:
What is solar activity and its influences on climate?
What is the Milankovitch cycle and its consequences?
What is the cause of ocean dynamics?
What are atmospheric composition and its structure?
How do energy transformations in the atmosphere influence weather patterns and stability?
What is the cause of global wind patterns and their consequences?
What are the features of the weather of the GBA?
Visit:
Meteorological institutions
The Solid Earth (12 hours)
Major concepts:
Basic principles of geology
The cause of geological characteristics of the GBA
Topics:
What are plate tectonics?
What are large-scale Earth processes and formations?
What are the composition and small-scale structures of the Earth’s materials, such as rock, mineral, and ore deposits?
What are the features of the geology of the GBA?
Field study:
On-site study of volcanic rock columns and/or rocky coastlines
The Ocean (8 hours)
Major concepts:
Basic principles of oceanology
Topics:
What is thermohaline circulation and its influence on long-term climate?
What is ocean-atmospheric circulation?
What is the cause of tsunamis?
How do erosion and deposition occur?
What are the marine features of the GBA, such as coastal features and water quality?
Case study of Hong Kong and Shenzhen (10 hours)
Major concepts:
Understanding of natural disasters
Basic principles of microclimate
Topics:
What is the cause of natural disasters in the cities?
What are the features of local weather patterns?
What are the oceanic and mineral resources in the South China Sea?
How does the natural environment influence the availability and distribution of natural resources?
Visit and/or seminar:
High-tech marine companies and/or seminars on marine technology.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Experiencing and Rethinking Science and Technology in Agriculture
courses.description: Throughout human history, we have developed different ways to strive for living in nature. Among which, agriculture is the foundation of all sedentary civilizations as it systematically provides food and other products to sustain human lives. It is an art that integrates knowledge of nature with human needs and values, evolving side by side with the development of science and technology. Today, with the advancement of scientific technology, the highly industrialized modern agriculture has greatly increased food production to support the global population growth. Yet it also brings global ethical concerns regarding sustainability, food safety, biotechnology, pollution, etc. In the past decades, increasing attention has been given to permaculture, an alternative agricultural practice that emphasizes the development of durable and self-sufficient ecosystems in farming. Permaculture is not only a practice of sustainable food production, it is also a philosophy of living with nature.In this course, students will learn through lectures the basic knowledge about modern agriculture and its applications of science and technology; understand the fundamental principles, philosophy, and practice of permaculture; discuss the ethical issues related to the use of science and technology in modern agriculture; reflect on the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, such as “Zero Hunger”, “Affordable and Clean Energy”, “Sustainable Cities and Communities”, and “Responsible Consumption and Reproduction”. Students will also experience the practices of modern agriculture and permaculture by making site-visits to enterprises of the agricultural industry, and to institutes practicing permaculture. Students who finish this course will be able to describe and compare the major principles and practices of modern agriculture and those of permaculture, analyze the ethical issues related to modern agriculture in contemporary societies, and formulate personal views on how to live more ethically with nature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #2 Zero Hunger
SDG-GE #6 Clean Water and Sanitation
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
Experiential Learning Course
courses.course_syllabus:
There are three main topics to be covered in this course
:
(1) Modern agriculture
The following issues will be covered:
– Brief history of agriculture
The science and technology applied in modern agriculture will also be introduced, including:
– Use of machines
– Use of chemicals
– Application of biotechnology
Understanding of modern agriculture will be deepened by site-visits to modern agricultural enterprises, where students can experience the farming scale and productivity in modern agriculture.
(2) Permaculture
Permaculture is an alternative agricultural practice emphasizing the development of sustainable and self-sufficient agricultural ecosystems. In contrast to modern agriculture, permaculture promotes high-science and low-technology. The following issues about permaculture will be covered:
– Basics principles of permaculture
– Philosophy of living with nature
– Practical knowledge of permaculture
Students’ understanding of permaculture will be reinforced by site-visits and hand-on practice in permaculture institutes.
(3) Agricultural ethics
Modern agriculture has brought not only increased food supply, but also global concerns of ethical issues. The following issues will be covered:
– Sustainability and SDGs
– Food safety
– Biotechnology
– Pollution
Students will learn the agricultural ethics related to the use of science and technology in modern agriculture. By comparing modern agriculture and permaculture, students will be able to reflect on the ethical issues in modern agriculture and ponder on how an ethical way of living with nature can be developed. Students will also reflect on sustainability related to SDG #2 “Zero Hunger”, SDG #7 “Affordable and Clean Energy”, SDG #11 “Sustainable Cities and Communities”, SDG #12 “Responsible Consumption and Reproduction”, SDG #13 “Climate Change”, SDG #14 “Life below Water” and SDG #15 “Life on Land”. The reflection will be deepened by the site-visits to the modern farmlands and permaculture institutes, and group discussion with the course instructor and classmates.
The courses will be designed in three parts
:
Part I Lectures in CUHK
– Two whole-day lectures will be given to introduce the three main topics mentioned above. Students are required to take a quiz after the lectures.
Part II Study-trip
– By experiencing modern agriculture and permaculture in real-life situations and hand-on practices, students will understand better the situations, dilemmas and ethical issues of global concern regarding modern agriculture. A six-day study-trip visiting modern farmlands and permaculture institutes will be organized to deepen students’ understanding and reflection on the three main topics mentioned above. In the study-trip, there will be site-visits, talks, practices and discussion sessions covering modern agriculture, permaculture, agricultural ethics and SDGs.
– Australia is at the top priority for the study-trip because she has well-established modern agriculture industry and permaculture practice. She is also the origin of permaculture. Taiwan is the second priority for the trip because it also has good modern agriculture industry and permaculture practice, although the scale is smaller than Australia. Due to the increasing popularity of permaculture worldwide, other countries and regions with good permaculture practices will also be considered..
Part III Seminar in CUHK
– A seminar will be organised to consolidate the ideas covered in the lectures and the study-trip. Students are required to give group presentations to apply what they have learnt in the lectures and the trip. They are required to write individual final paper afterwards.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Rethinking Environmental Protection in the Greater Bay Area
courses.description: Environmental protection is an important part of modern civilization for the fact that human life and the sustainable development of society are based on natural resources from the environment. While there are common principles and practices for protecting the environment, local contexts might add to the intricacy between humans and their environment, and thus create multiple perspectives for intellectual pursuits. For example, cities in the Greater Bay Area (GBA) share and enjoy a lot of marine resources in the Pearl River Delta. However, coastal cities in the GBA, including Hong Kong and Shenzhen have been heavily impacted by pollution arising from rapid economic transformations and industrial developments in the last few decades. For such a global issue, concerted efforts have been made in scientific studies, implementation of international policies and strengthening of local governance to restore the damaged environment and properly manage our natural resources. Progress has been made but environmental issues remain a huge challenge to mankind.This course aims to engage students in re-examining some current strategies for environmental protection at national, regional, local and even personal levels, by guiding them to study selected prevailing environmental problems, general practices of the society and some representative interregional collaborations in the GBA. While general principles in environmental science will be outlined, this course will focus on water resources, management of pollution in the coastal area and regional collaborations upon the issues. To gain first-hand experience in the present situation of their own city and neighbouring regions, students from CUHK and CUHK(SZ) will participate in field trips and scientific investigations. Tutorial discussions and writing assignments are learning opportunities for students to reflect on and evaluate the implementation of current environmental policies and interregional collaborations in the Greater Bay Area, in terms of the possibilities those policies and collaborations have brought, their significance and issues arising from them. The course serves as a platform across human experience and knowledge for students to exchange ideas, propose new ideas and embark on the journey to a better world as local inhabitants and global citizens.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Environmental Science (ENSC); and Earth and Environmental Sciences (EESC) Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
courses.learning_outcomes:
Describe the basic concepts in environmental sciences and explain the significance of environmental protection.
Examine the environmental protection policies in Hong Kong and Mainland China with reference to the basic concepts in environmental sciences.
Identify up-to-date scientific knowledge and achievements in pollution management and conservation of natural resources in the Greater Bay Area.
Analyse first-hand data from field trips and compare with open reports provided by monitoring parties.
Evaluate current works on environmental issues and propose regional or interregional collaborations to build a sustainable future.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Basic information of Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (
lecture)
Major concepts:
Bay area; Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area.
Topics:
The Past and Present of Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area.
What can we learn from other global bay areas (Tokyo Bay Area, San Francisco Bay Area and New York Bay Area)?
II. Basic concepts in environmental science (lecture)
Major concepts:
Natural capital; ecological footprint; ecosystem; pollution
​Topics:
What happens to energy and matter in an ecosystem? How are our ecological footprint affecting the earth? How do we study ecosystem?
What is pollution? How can we deal with water pollution?
Why do we have environmental problems? What is an environmentally sustainable society? What are some major environmental worldviews? How can we live more sustainably?
III. Environmental protection in Hong Kong
(a) Environmental protection policies in Hong Kong (lecture)
Topics:
How can we implement more sustainable and just environment policies?
​Review of current laws and regulations for environment protection in Hong Kong
(b) Biodiversity in the intertidal area (lecture)
Major concepts:
Biodiversity, mudflat, mudflat ecology, biological invasions
Topics:
What is mud? What is intertidal area?
What are the indicators of mudflat ecology?
What is the indicator of biological invasions?
What is the impact of biological invasions?
How can we use statistics to evaluate the mudflat ecology?
(c) Fisheries and Aquaculture in Hong Kong (lecture)
Major concepts:
Aquaculture
Topics:
Review of the fisheries and aquaculture in the context of environment issues
(d) T-Park or another site of a similar nature (field trip)
Major concepts:
Water resources, water pollution, sludge treatment, zero waste
Topics:
Review of the strategies of wastewater and sludge treatment in Hong Kong
(e) Oyster restoration and ecological study in Pak Nai (field trip)
Topics:
Review of the mudflat ecology and biodiversity in the area between Hong Kong and Shenzhen
IV. Environmental protection in Shenzhen
(a) Chemical pollutants in water and soil (lecture)
Major concepts:
Chemical pollutants, toxicity
Topics:
The sources of pollution and the species of pollutants
Level and toxic effect of pollutants
Assessment, treatment and removal strategies
(b) Ecological economics, environmental protection policies in Mainland China & collaborations in GBA (lecture)
Major concepts:
Ecological economics, regional cooperation
Topics:
How are economic systems related to the biosphere?
Review of the environmental policies (for water pollution, air pollution, biodiversity and marine utilization) in mainland China and Shenzhen
The possibility, strategies and actions of collaborations in GBA
(c) Water Supplies Department in Shenzhen or another site of a similar nature (field trip)
Topics:
Review of the strategies of wastewater and sludge treatment in Shenzhen
(d) Coral Protection Organization in Dapeng or Nature Reserve Inner Lingding Island or another site of a similar nature (field trip)
Topics:
Review of the marine environment and biodiversity in GBA
(e) Xiangmi Park in Shenzhen (field trip)
Topics:
Review of the low impact development strategies and biodiversity in Shenzhen city
V. Laboratory test to assess pollutants in environmental samples (lab work)
Topics:
Pollutants assessment for some environmental samples
VI. Overall reflection and evaluation
(a) A review on the progress in environmental challenges in Hong Kong and Mainland China (tutorial discussion).
(b) Reflection on sustainable development (tutorial discussion).
(c) Regional collaboration for a sustainable future (student seminar)

courses.title: Robots in Action

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1

courses.description: This course is designed to educate students with little or no technical background and experience to have a general understanding and a fun learning experience of the charismatic subject of robots. Our society is on the verge of a new era of technology convergence: robotic devices are envisioned to become a nearly ubiquitous part of our day-to-day lives. New technologies such as wireless communication and voice and visual recognition will make robots become behaviour-based, cognitive and biologically inspired humanoids. Fundamental social, economical, and technological issues of a human-machine society will be identified and discussed in interactive sessions. This learning process transcends the conventional boundaries between technology and other disciplines, and it is facilitated with a series of demonstrative sessions which present students with opportunities to observe, evaluate, examine, and interact with a variety of commercial robots and humanoids. Guided by internal and external experts, students will also focus on a specific social, business or technology issue, identifying and exploring potential solutions with robotic and automation technology that could potentially impact the quality of our life. In this exploration process, students are encouraged to apply their personal background and interest to conceive and experiment with the aid of popular robot kits. The course will cultivate students with enriched perspectives of a future society.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Energy Engineering, Energy and Environmental Engineering, and Mechanical and Automation Engineering Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is built around the fundamental understanding of the technological, economic and social issues of robots, the basic components and subsystems that make up robots and the development of critical perspectives of new automation technologies. The cornerstone of the class involves evaluation of robotic roles in our daily lives and exploring potential solutions with robotic technology. Upon completion of the course, students should have achived the following outcomes:
a.
understand the various components of robotic systems and how they work together;
b.
appreciate the potential value of robotic technology to the society;
c.
develop skills of concept exploration, critical thinking and teamwork.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Plan:
Part 1 Basic concepts and the making of robots
- 
their physical composition and their behaviour functionalities
- 
historical perspectives and current state of the technology
- 
social, economic and behavioural impacts of the technology
- 
a robot-augmented future society
Part 2 Understanding the roles, functions and the contemporary use of robots (Demonstrative sessions)
- 
field observations and evaluation of robots in the service industry (e.g. restaurant service and entertainment robots);
- 
examination and interaction with robots (e.g. hospital robots, robot assistants and humanoid robots in laboratories)
- 
reflections on the characteristics and values of robotic technology from the social, economic and technological perspective (An individual essay for each student on an issued learned in the interactive sessions will be required)
Part 3 Laboratory projects for students to identify and choose a problem with a potential robotic solution
- 
problem justification and feasibility study
- 
introduction to engineering problem solving process;
- 
concept exploration with robot kits and formulation of design task;
- 
critical thinking and teamwork;
- 
a final project summary and report for each project team.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Relativity and Quantum Mechanics: A Conceptual Introduction
courses.description: An introduction to the concepts and implications of relativity and quantum mechanics, unarguably the two most important theories of modern physics that have far-reaching consequences on science and technology and profound impacts on human thoughts. This course aims at a non-mathematical exposition of the central ideas and the development of relativity and quantum mechanics. How they transform the way we live and think will also be discussed. Topics include space-time, energy-mass conversion, gravitation, compact stars and black holes, cosmology, wave-particle duality, quantum mechanical bound states, tunneling, applications in modern technology such as lasers, superconductors and GPS.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Physics Majors; and students in the following concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Physical Sciences.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. basic understanding o f relativity and quantum mechanics
2. basic appreciation o f how these two theories change the world
3. basic understanding o f the applications o f relativity and quantum mechanics
4. appreciation o f how modem science and scientific method emerge, and how scientists construct theories and models to describe Nature
5. enhanced curiosity in Nature

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Plants for Treasure and Pleasure
courses.description: This course aims to provide an overview of the biodiversity of plants (also including algae) and their applications as 1) food and nutrients; 2) clothing and construction materials; 3) drugs and functional food; 4) landscaping and environment remedy stuffs; 5) hallucinogenic and narcotic agents; 6) fuels and energy; and 7) feeds, fertilizers and pesticides. The discoveries and economic applications of plants will be further discussed and reviewed, through comparing the traditional and scientific approaches of using plants, and introducing the innovation methods, genetically modified foods, and commodity markets.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for majoring in LSCI; not for BCME; and student concent of Biological Sciences; Biotechnology; Environmental Studies; and Food and Nutrition.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
recognise the major groups of plants and their characteristics and properties.
describe the traditional and scientific approaches and innovations in the discovery and economic applications of plants.
identify the major groups of secondary metabolites and examples of their economic uses.
judge the benefits and potential dangers in the modern uses of plants, in-particular on the use of GM-plants and fuel-plants.
recognise and give examples on the applications of plants for (i) food and nourishment, (ii) clothing and construction materials, (iii) combating diseases and maintaining health, (iii) landscaping and environment remedy, (iv) altering minds and mental states, (v) fuels and energy, and (vi) husbandry and agriculture.
recognise photosynthesis as the primary process for capturing sunlight and production of food.
courses.course_syllabus:
Theme 1: Plant biodiversity and source of starch and other useful chemicals
Contents: (i) overview of the biodiversity of plants (also including algae), (ii) photosynthesis as a primary process for capturing solar energy and production of food, and (iii) secondary metabolites manufactured by plants as a source of useful chemicals for treasure and pleasure.
Theme 2: Traditional and scientific approaches to using plants for treasure and pleasure
Contents: (i) overview of the characteristics of the traditional, and scientific approaches to the selection, modification, and processing of plants to cater to human needs and desires, (ii) logistics and commodity markets for plants of economic value, and (iii) benefits and dangers in the modern uses of plants.
Theme 3: A survey of plants for treasure and pleasure
Contents: a survey of the applications of plants for (i) food and nourishment, (ii) clothing and construction material, (iii) combating diseases and maintaining health, (iv) landscaping and environment remedy, (v) altering minds and mental states, (vi) fuels and energy, and (vii) husbandry and agriculture.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Wonders and Insights in Biology
courses.description: Biology is the study of life. Complex life is built from some molecules that slowly evolved into diverse living organisms, which then interact with the environment to form ecosystems and finally shape the biosphere where we all live in. Studies of the biological world allow us to understand more on how life has evolved and lead to significant advancement in our ability to improve living quality, but at the same time create a lot of controversies and problems. This course firstly aims to provide a systematic and comprehensive view on the biological world, starting from the simplest DNA to simple single-celled organisms, and then to more complicated living organisms, and finally to the most complex ecosystems and biosphere; and to guide students to appreciate the Wonders and majesty of the biological world. Students will also be introduced examples of how insights from studying the biological world can improve our health, living quality and environment, and may affect the future societal development. Students will be introduced to examples that are relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals including SDG #3 “Good Heath and Well Being, SDG #7 “Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG #13 “Climate Action” and SDG #15 “Life on Land”. The important roles of biotechnology will be discussed, such as how human diseases can be prevented and treated, and how global climate change can be mitigated.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.learning_outcomes:
To recognize how life is organized from molecules into organisms and how they live with nature
To develop concepts on how nature shapes her inhabitants through the process of natural selection
To give examples of what humans have learnt from nature to solve their life problems and to improve their living quality
To explain how human activities affect the environment and its remediation
To apply some basic principles and knowledge of biological sciences to real life situations
To appraise the impact of modern life styles of humans on nature with a scientific basis
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is structured around the increasing complexity of the biosphere. Starting with the smallest biomolecules, namely DNA, students will learn how life is built. The simplest life form then evolved to arrays of organisms. Such biodiversity and complex interactions among organisms produce diverse ecosystems and, collectively, the biosphere we now know. Important components of the biosphere and how they fit in will be introduced. Students will learn and appreciate the origin of life and the evolutionary process, biodiversity and ecosystems, and partnerships in the living world. After taking this part, the students should be able to appreciate the Wonders and majesty of life. Topics include:
Origin of Life*
The Master Molecule of Life - DNA*
Inside the Living Cell*
From Beginning to Now - Evolution in Action*
The Incredible Biodiversity - Plants and Animals*
When Lives Interact - Community and Ecosystem*
Advances in biology have led to tremendous understanding of the biosphere. Insight and knowledge gained has transformed into a wide spectrum of applications and new realm of technologies which lead to a better and more sustainable future. A vast array of examples will be used to demonstrate to students how genetic engineering, biomimicry and bioremediation alike are now seamlessly integrated into our daily life. Critical reviews and everyday examples will entice students to view our world in a fresh perspective and to appreciate the wonders and insights of biology. The students should be able to realize how insights from studying the biological world better our environment, improve our quality of life, and affect our future societies. Topics include:
Living Better with Biotechnology* (SDG #3)
The Never-ending War between Human and Microbes
Stopping Cancer before It Starts* (SDG #3)
Fighting Cancer with New Weapons
Learning New Tricks from Other Organisms* (SDG #3, #7 and #13)
Relationships Between Organisms* (SDG #15)
Sexual Selection
Can We Turn Back Global Warming with Biotechnology* (SDG #7, #13 and #15)
Repairing Our Environment by Bioremediation
Solving the Solid Waste Problem with Microbes
A Green and Renewable Source of Energy - Biofuel* (SDG #7)
* These are Core Topics

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Great Discoveries in Life Sciences
courses.description: This course aims at deciphering how the discoveries by the work of some famous scientists in the field of life sciences has affected our daily life and our society. The course first provides students with the general knowledge of some basic processes in life, followed by how this knowledge has helped us to cope with the natural adversities such as diseases. The improvements of our quality of life by the biotechnological advances and how the development in life sciences has revolutionized our lives in life sciences will also be discussed. Finally, how the development in life sciences has brought revolutionizing impacts on our lives, civilization, and modernization will be presented. Through a series of learning activities, students are encouraged to comprehend and to connect the discoveries in life sciences to daily scenarios. This course is particularly suitable for students who are not life-science or medicine majors and who want to understand more on how discoveries in life sciences have transformed the way we think and live throughout the centuries.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences, BMEG Major & NSCI Major in YBSC, YBTC, YENS & YFNC and student taken BCHE2030,3030, 3080, BIOL2120,BMEG2000,2010 or LSCI1002
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
recognize how life sciences can benefit our daily life
comprehend basic knowledge in life sciences
analyze and comment on the issues related to life sciences, for example, test tube babies and cloning in life sciences
develop practical skills in communication and critical thinking through different types of learning activities
gain learning methodologies that promote life-long learning in life science subjects
courses.course_syllabus:
This course focuses on how the discoveries by some famous scientists in life sciences, including many Nobel laureates, have influenced our daily life. The course first introduces the major breakthroughs in the life sciences which facilitate the understanding of the basic processes in life, followed by illustration of how these discoveries can prepare humans to fight off the natural adversities. Finally, the course covers the several major technological advances in life sciences and how they have contributed to human civilization and modernization.
Theme 1:
Basic knowledge in Life Sciences
This theme provides students with the basic knowledge in life sciences that prepares them for Theme 2 and Theme 3.
How does life evolve? – The theory of natural selection
How are genetic materials passed on through generations? – DNA and genes
Why are genetic materials important for life? – The translation of genetic materials to functional proteins
Theme 2:
Life Science Discoveries to Benefit Health
This theme illustrates how the discoveries in life sciences have improved human health.
What is infection? – The story of microbes
How do humans battle infection? - The concept of infection and immunity
What is cancer? – Cancer-causing viruses and genes vs. tumour-suppressor genes
Theme 3:
Life Science Discoveries and
T
echnological
A
dvances
This theme focuses on the remarkable technological advances that improve the living standard of humans.
How did modern biotechnology arise? – Advances in genetic engineering
How does biotechnology benefit humans? - Infertility problems and organ failure

courses.description: This course aims at providing students with majors in other academic (non-life sciences, non-medical) disciplines with an overview of nutritional sciences and their applications for everyday life and health issues. This course also aims at increase the awareness of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to food and nutrition.The course is composed of 4 themes. Theme 1 will introduce basic concepts of nutritional sciences and the nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life in humans. Theme 2 will address the relationship between nutrition and some common nutrition-related diseases. Weight management will also be included in theme 2. Theme 3 will discuss some diet and nutrition controversial issues. Theme 4 will cover some selected local and global nutritional issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences, BMEG Majors and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. identify the functions of nutrients, and symptoms resulted from excessive and deficient nutrients intake
2. recognize nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life in humans
3. describe the relationships between nutrition and some common diseases
4. analyze nutritional controversies through applications of the basic knowledge of nutritional sciences
5. assess nutritional status using simple nutritional assessment methods
6. develop simple strategies for weight management and healthy eating habits
7. apply basic knowledge of nutritional sciences in daily life to promote healthy eating
8. identify local and global nutritional issues that influence our eating behaviors
9. increase awareness of SDGs, particularly the goals that are food and nutrition related.
courses.course_syllabus:
Theme 1: Understanding of Basic Nutrition
(1) Functions of nutrients and their food sources;
(2) Nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life, from pregnancy, infancy, adolescence to adults and elderly (SDG 3)
Theme 2: Nutrition, Health, and Diseases
(1) Recognition of the whole spectrum of malnutrition, importance of weight management and healthy eating (SDG 3, 12)
(2) The causes and development of some common nutrition-related diseases, e.g. heart diseases, diabetes, cancer, digestive problems etc., (SDG 3)
Theme 3: Nutrition Myths: Facts or Fallacies
(1) Effectiveness of popular diet; (2) Food and acne; (3) Organic foods; (4) Antioxidants (e.g. red wine,
green tea) in relation to body health, etc.;
Theme 4: Local/Global Nutritional Issues
(1) General nutritional status in HK population and the challenges in promoting health and nutrition;
(2) Global nutritional issues and the relating factors, e.g. poverty and food security, agriculture production in relation to climate change, triple-burden, and food shortage, food consumption and food waste (SDG 1, 2, 3, 12, 13)

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Biochemistry and Physical Activities
courses.description: This course aims at providing students with some key concepts in Life Sciences, and Biochemistry in particular, through a series of daily life examples in real world situations. The course will first introduce the basic functions of our body, followed by some selected cases to illustrate how our body works during physical activities. The course is designed to let students without prior knowledge of Life Sciences acquire basic understanding and interest in Biochemistry, which can be applied in daily life in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine,School of LSCI; BMEG,ESHE,SPED,PESH,NSCI(YBSC,YBTC,YENS,YFNC)Majors; students taken BCHE2030,3030,3080,BIOL2120,BMEG2000,2010,LSCI1002,PHPC2007,SPED2520,2540
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
describe the basic functions of our body
explain the key physiological mechanisms of the human body during physical activities
apply the knowledge of Biochemistry in specific physical activities, such as sports
analyze how various environmental factors can affect the human body during physical activities
plan and to make informed judgment to respond to the injuries picked up during physical activities with the knowledge of Biochemistry
courses.course_syllabus:
The focus of this course is to illustrate how the key concepts in Life Sciences, in particular Biochemistry, can be applied to our daily life in real world situations. The course will first introduce the basic functions of our body, followed by the adaptation mechanisms of our body to external factors such as physical activities and environmental conditions. Selected topics on how we can actively improve our health will be covered in the second part of the course.
Part
1:
Basic Principles of the Functions of Our Body
This part explains several important functions of our body from molecular to cellular, and from organs to systems levels so as to equip students to further understand and analyze the cases presented in the second part of the course.
The chemistry of life
Bioenergetics and material transport within the body
The skeletomuscular system
Molecular sensors of the environment and within the body
Adaptations of the body to the external environment
Part
2:
Case Studies of Biochemistry in Various Life Functions
This part presents several representative cases to illustrate (1) how our body maintains normal functions during physical activities and in extreme conditions and (2) how we can apply the knowledge of Biochemistry in everyday life scenarios.
How does our body respond to extreme environmental conditions? – Adaptation responses to extreme heat, cold, and oxygen level
How does our body respond to demanding physical activities? – Adaptation responses to the high energy output during a flight-or-fight reaction
How does our body utilize nutrients during physical activities? - Nutrient bioenergetics in exercise and training
What is stress and how does our body cope with it? – Hormones secreted under stress response
What happens during a sport injury? – Biochemical mechanisms of the traumatic injuries after sports
How can I feel the pain of an injury or a disease? – The mechanisms of pain and analgesia
How do I get tired and recover? – The fatigue process

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Food Safety and Processing Technology
courses.description: In modern cities, a wide assortment of food products is available in the markets and consumers are able to enjoy these delicious foods conveniently and safely. Behind the scenes of food enjoyment, lots of science and technology has been applied in their manufacturing processes to ensure that the food products are preserved in high standards of quality, nutrition and safety. Among those food manufacturing and processing methods, however, some of them are quite controversial and thus arouse many public concerns over food safety and security issues. This course is designed for the general students to provide them with some key concepts and scientific knowledge in food preservation, processing technology and food safety control, as well as to explore the interactive relationships between them. Through learning the basic properties of foodborne hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems, students are able to enhance the understandings on the principles and practices of respective food preservation methods and processing technologies. Meanwhile, the potential risks and adverse effects of particular food processing technologies will be discussed. Furthermore, some highly concerning topics and incidents about food safety will be analysed based on scientific facts and discussed from different perspectives. After finishing the course, students are encouraged to use the acquired knowledge to make better food choices, distinguish the fallacies about food and appraise the impact of modern technology on human food safety and security.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences Majors and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to be able to:
identify the foodborne hazards in various aspects and describe their properties
elucidate the causes and mechanisms of foodborne diseases
identify the applications of food preservation methods and technologies in daily food products and explain their working principles
apply the knowledge to make better food choices and safer domestic food preparations
analyse the contemporary food issues with scientific discipline and make informed judgment in some controversies of food concerns
appraise the pros and cons of food processing technologies and evaluate their impact on food safety and security
courses.course_syllabus:
This course mainly focuses on the food safety and the related processing technology. The course begins with introducing the common foodborne hazards that people come across in daily lives. Then, the principles of various contemporary food preservation methods and processing technologies protecting foods from spoilage or contamination are explicated. Finally, selected topics of food issues and safety concerns are studied. The relationship between food processing and safety are analysed through those specific discussions.
Part 1. Foodborne Hazards
The initial part of the course provides students with a basic understanding on the biological and chemical food hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems. The fundamental knowledge about food microorganism will be elucidated, which include the general property of microbes, the common characteristic of foodborne pathogen and the mechanism of how they cause the foodborne illnesses. On the other side, the food chemicals including toxin, allergen and contaminant that leading adverse effects to human will be introduced and some mechanisms of common food poisoning and allergy will be explained.
Biological Hazards in Food
Understanding of food microorganisms
Essential conditions for food microbe growth
Characteristics and sources of foodborne pathogens
Causes and effects of foodborne illnesses: infection and intoxication
Chemical Hazards in Food
Nature of food toxins
Existence and origins of food contaminants
Understanding of food allergens
Causes and effects of food poisoning and hypersensitive
Part 2. Food Preservation Method and Processing Technology
This part covers the theories and practices of food preservation and safety control. The basic principles and mechanisms of modern-day food processing technologies for the preservation purpose will be explained. Moreover, the concept and principle of Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP), which is a prevalent food safety control system executing in modern food premises, will be briefly introduced in this section.
Food Processing
Principles and objectives of food processing
Effects of processing treatments on food properties

Food Preservation Method and Technology
High temperature processing: pasteurization and sterilization
Low temperature processing: chilling and freezing
Control of atmospheres in package
Control of water activity
Control of pH
Food irradiation
Functions and regulations of food additives
Hurdle Technology
Food Safety System: HACCP
Basic concept of HACCP: from farm to fork
Seven principles to develop HACCP plan for a food production
Methodology of risk assessment
Part 3. Food Issues and Concerns
Selected food issues and safety concerns will be presented in the last part of the course. The background of individual food safety topics will be introduced and the credibility of the concerns will be analysed based on the scientific knowledge and facts. The correlation between food manufacturing and safety issues will be studied. The limitations of the current food safety control system are also revealed. And the social impacts of those food safety issues will be discussed in the lesson as well.
Food Safety Topics
Foodborne outbreaks
Food frauds
Genetically modified foods
Uses of hormones and food additives

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Biotechnology in biodiversity, conservation, environment and sustainability
courses.description: In recent years, the United Nations had proposed a global plan aiming to end poverty and protect the globe, and ensure that people living on this planet enjoy peace and prosperity by 2030. The goal is going to be achieved and performed by 17 integrated subdivisions, which are also known as the sustainable development goals (SDGs). Biodiversity, conservation, environmental management, and related technologies are essential and are brought together under this bigger theme of sustainability. Biotechnology, here thus plays a great role, as it infiltrates in different part of our lives — from the food we eat to how we collect them, the drugs we take to treat illnesses, the fuel we use to power up devices and even the conservation of biodiversity and the environmental health. While biotechnology is a broad discipline that exploits different biological processes, organisms, cells or cellular components to develop new and effective technologies and is a newly emerged and an ongoing field in biological sciences, it offers opportunities to aid achieving different global matters that are happening currently or in the foreseeable future, especially issues relating but not limited to food crisis, one health, energy shortage, sustainable infrastructure and biodiversity in different habitats, etc.This course provides a wide scope of knowledge relating to biotechnology that aims to stimulate thoughts and broaden the horizon of students from different background. It also allows the students to embrace the beauty and understand the constraint, including ethical, social, environmental and technological challenges of biotechnology. This course focuses on three major themes: 1). Introduction of the basic biotechnology knowledge of genetics and extended biotechnology techniques, 2). Showcases of the latest biotechnological developments and applications in various aspects of life sciences, 3). Discussion of key values of biotechnology and the philosophical, moral and ethical issues of biotechnology. Ultimately, this course aims at raising the awareness and promote the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to SDG#2 Zero Hunger, SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being, SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy, SDG#9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities, SDG#14 Life Below Water and SDG#15 Life On Land, to the students.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for majors in School of Life Sciences & students in the con areas of Natural Sciences Prog: Biological Sciences; Biotechnology; Environmental Studies; or Food & Nutrition. Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH" or "UGFN” as prefix.
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #2 Zero Hunger
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. acquire the basic knowledge of biotechnology
2. understand the everyday life and environmental applications of biotechnology
3. evaluate the power and constraint, including ethical, social, environmental and technological challenges of conservation and environmental biotechnology
4. address relevant sustainable development goals (SDGs) with environmental biotechnology in everyday lives
5. develop practical skills in writing and presentation, as well as critical thinking through different learning activities

courses.description: The course is designed to illustrate the basic principles of chemistry (e.g., atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular properties, etc.) via case studies of some celebrated accidental discoveries (and wild claims) in science. Topics include nuclei, atoms, small molecules, radioactivity, polymers, and analytical methods in chemistry. Real-life applications and trivia are also covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for CHEM Majors; students in concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Analytical and Testing Sciences; or Chemical Sciences; students who have taken CHEM2382,UGEB2380,2410,2420 ,2440
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
The students would learn the basic structure of matter.
They would treat “unexpected” phenomena more seriously before they discard them as fluke.
They would realize the role of serendipity in discovery.
Good science requires not only critical thinking but also a sense of creativity, and occasionally wild imaginations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Basic concepts:
atoms and molecules: their structures and roles in the formation of bulk materials
materials: important materials such as metals/alloys and polymers, their microscopic structures and applications in daily life
intermolecular forces: their origins and importance in the formation of molecules
radioactivity and nuclear processes: the phenomenon, the types and applications
organic chemistry: examples (such as polymers) and importance for industry and daily life
Analytical techniques:
physical methods: (such as density and refractive index measurement) for chemical analysis

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Chemistry of Life

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 404

courses.description: (UGEB2380 is double-coded with CHEM2382.)  This course aims to introduce the roles of chemistry in different stages of our life. 'Topics include: 1. basic chemical knowledge related to life science; 2. origin of life - essential elements. water, and proteins; 3. growing up - food. nutrients, and hormones; 4. medication: chemicals against diseases; 5. messing up - narcotics, some stimulant drugs, and hallucinogens ( e g heroin. ketamine, and ecstasy); 6. ageing; 7. the mystery of heredity - nucleic acids and the Double Helix.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Fac of Med; Sch of LSCI; CHEM Majors; NSCI Majors in Analy & Test Sci/ Chemical Sci concentration; students who have taken CHEM2382, UGEB2370, 2410, 2420 or 2440
Co-requisite:UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001(only applicable to students in 4-year curr)
courses.learning_outcomes: Students taking this course will learn some basic chemical concepts and knowledge related to life science. They will also understand the role of chemistry in various stages of our life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Introduction
I
Some basic concepts in chemistry
will
be introduced: What is chemistry? Atomic structures, isotopes, molecules and chemical bonding, physical and chemical properties of matters, physical and chemical changes.
Week
2
Introduction II
Oxidation and reduction reactions, acids and bases, the Periodic Table, and a brief introduction to organic chemistry.
Week
3
Origin of Life I
The essential elements and their importance to organisms water and its properties. amino acids and peptides, structures and properties of' proteins, hair-waving and the mad cow disease.
Week 4
Origin
of
Life II
An overview on the chemistry of enzymes and the concept of stereochemistry (chirality) will he introduced
Week 5
Growing-Up I
The chemical and biochemical aspects of nutrition will be discussed. An overview on carbohydrates and lipids.
Week 6
Growing-Up II
An overview on vitamins. Hormones - chemical messengers in our body.
Week
7
Mid-term examination
Week
8
Medication
I
- Chemicals against diseases
Analgesic, antibiotics and anti-viral drugs. The development of some common medicine such
as
aspirin and acetaminophen will be introduced. Moreover, the chemistry of antibiotics and anaesthetics will also be described.
Week
9
Medication II -Chemicals against AIDS
The immune system. How far can we knock down HIV? AZT and the Cocktail Treatment.
Week 10
Messing Up-Some stimulant drugs
Caffeine and nicotine as common stimulants. Cocaine, amphetamine, and ecstasy as potent stimulant drugs.
Week 11
Messing Up-Narcotics and Hallucinogens
Narcotics - the three opium alkaloids: morphine, codeine, and heroin. Hallucinogens - cannabis. lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and ketamine.
Week 12
Ageing
What causes ageing? The secrets of ageing will be revealed from a molecular point of view.
Week
13
The mystery of heredity
A walk through the chemistry of nucleic acids and the Double Helix,
Week 14
Nucleic acids and genetics
The mystery behind genetic coding. Biosynthesis of proteins. Genetic diseases.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Chemistry for a Sustainable Future
courses.description: Chemical pollution has a substantial impact on human health and well-being. At the same time, the global demand for energy and natural resources is growing, leading to more pollution or even climate changes. In order to integrate environmental sustainability with economic growth, it is important to develop clean energy research technology, environmentally sound industrial processes and sustainable production patterns.This course is designed for students with minimal background in chemistry to acquire chemical knowledge related to sustainable development. It introduces the basic concepts of chemistry that are essential for students to understand the scientific aspects of environmental and human health challenges such as pollution and energy crisis. This course also discusses the principles of green chemistry and explain how they are applied to real-life technologies to create a sustainable future for the world.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for CHEM,ENSC Majors; NSCI concentration in Analytical & Testing Sciences; Chemical Sciences; or Environmental Studies; students who have taken CHEM2382, UGEB2370,2380,2410,2420 or 2440
Co-requisite:Courses with course code prefix as "UGFH" or "UGFN"
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students who have finished this course are expected to:
1. Describe some basic concepts in chemistry ranging from atomic structure and chemical bonding to chemical reactions.
2. Identify the current environmental and human health challenges.
3. Explain the principles of green chemistry and the importance of chemistry to sustainable development.
4. Evaluate the applications of chemical knowledge and innovative technologies in achieving a sustainable future.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Astronomy
courses.description: A qualitative and non-mathematical survey of major ideas in astronomy. Topics covered will include: earth and sky, moon, calendar and time keeping, origin of modern astronomy, light and telescope, starlight and atoms, the sun, binary stars and their significance, stellar evolution, neutron stars and black holes, Milky Way, galaxies, quasars, the structure of the universe, solar system, meteorites, asteroids and comets. This course will include one night observation. This course aims at introducing basic concepts rather than mathematical and factual details. Lectures are designed not only to present a volume of knowledge, but also to arouse students' curiosity in how nature works. Optional star-gazing trips as well as visits to Hong Kong Space Museum will be arranged.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to
- acquire a general knowledge of astronomy
- be able to appreciate the beauty of the universe and also the role played by astronomy in daily life
- understand the role played by astronomy in the development of science
- develop a sense of how a scientist approaches a problem and applies the scientific method to seek
answers
- develop a critical mind by learning to confront beliefs with observations

Part 2: Basic principles

- Relativity
Part 3: The solar system
Part 4: Stars

- Birth, evolution and death of stars
Part 5: Cosmology

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Origins – From Cosmos to Life
courses.description: The course aims at providing an introduction to the formation of the cosmos and the origin of life from an astrophysical perspective. The journey starts from the origin of the universe, and leads us through all the intermediate milestones such as the appearance of matter, the formation of galaxies, the formation of stars and planets, the appearance of simple life forms, and the evolution of life on Earth. Students can thus develop a complete picture of the current understanding of the emergence of life in the cosmos, and gain perspectives of the scientific method that allows us to arrive at the knowledge.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Physics Majors; students in the following concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Physical Sciences; and students who have taken PHYS2401, 2910, UGEB2401, 2411 or 2510.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will start with an overview of the formation of the cosmos, the subsequent important events in the history of the universe, and the origin of life. The important milestones include
1. The origin of the cosmos.
2. The appearance of the basic form of ordinary matter (protons, neutrons, and electrons) and light elements.
3. The formation of astronomical structures (galaxy clusters, galaxies, stars).
4. The appearance of heavy elements in various stages of star evolution.
5. The formation of planets.
6. The appearance of simple and complicated molecules.
7. The emergence of elementary life forms.
8. The process of evolution on Earth and history of life.
The brief overview of all these steps will provide the students with a mental map of how different pieces fit into the big picture.
Then some of the major topics will be discussed in depth. For each of those chosen topics, the discussion will be about what the latest understanding is, and how we arrived at the understanding. The latter part will focus on the logical arguments in understanding observations and experiments, so that the students can develop a solid understanding of how scientific method is applied throughout the process.
In particular, the topics which would be covered in depth are Topics 1, 3, 4, 5, and 8. They are chosen because we understand them the best, and because all of them can be explained in relatively simple way to non-experts.
Finally, the course will cover some latest developments of the research on the various steps. Some of the results could be more speculative, and would lead to some open questions for the students. If time permits, the course will also cover some topics about the implications of the whole “story”, e.g., are we alone in the universe?

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Chemistry in Action
courses.description: This course is designed for students with minimal background in Chemistry to acquire some general chemical knowledge related to our daily lives. The main objective is to acquaint students with some scientific background knowledge in chemistry. Students will be able to read about science and technology with some degree of critical judgment. This knowledge is essential for students to solve some problems in daily lives, such as to choose the right products and to compare the risk and benefits in some cases. This course will emphasize practical applications of chemistry to problems solving such as environmental pollution, energy resources, and human health. Some demonstrations will be carried out during classes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for stud major in prog by Fac of MED;not for Chem;students in the con. areas of NatSciProg: AnaTestSci;or ChemSci; students taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370,2380,2420or2440.Co-requisite:UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001(only applicable to stud admitted to 4year curri)
courses.learning_outcomes: The students in this course will learn some general chemical knowledge related to the environment and the products they encountered in their daily lives. Through this learning, the students will understand the world we live, our environment, and our body. The students will be able to do critical thinking and comparing the risks and benefits in daily Life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Introduction
Some general chemistry concepts will be taught, such as chemical bonding, concentration of a solution, brief introduction of atoms, elements and molecules, some organic compounds.
Week
2
Fitness and Health
Athletic performance, nutrition, vitamins, minerals, muscles, exercise, sports materials.
Week
3
Oxidation and Reduction
General concepts of oxidation-reduction, with examples in cut-apple, egg cooking, corrosion, photography, battery, breathalyzer used in road blocks, explosives. Demonstrations: Chemiluminescence, potato battery.
Week 4
Acid and Bases
Acid strength, pH values of some common substances, common acids and bases, phosphoric acid, household products with acids or bases, neutralization reactions, antacids, acid-base buffers, the blood system, acidosis, alkalosis.
Demonstrations: Red cabbage extract - the natural indicator
Week 5
Chemistry of Household Chemicals
The chemistry of surfactants, soaps and detergents, stain removal, bleach and whiteners, chemicals in dry cleaning, corrosive cleaners.
Week
6
Chemistry of cosmetics and haircare products
The general chemistry of cosmetics and toiletries, creams and lotions, lipsticks and powders, sunscreen products, perfumes, deodorants, shampoos, hair perm, hair dyeing.
Demonstration: ingredients in creams and lotions
Week
7
Food Additives
Food preservatives, antioxidants, sequestrants, food flavours, food enhancers, pH control in foods, anticaking agents, stabilizers and thickeners.
Demonstration: food colouring and other food additives
Week
8
Mid-term examination
Week 9
Toxic Substances
Poisons, lethal dose, corrosive poisons, metabolic poisons, neurotoxins, teratogens, mutagens, carcinogens
Week 10
Drugs
Development of medication, pharmacies, hormones used in sport, over the counter drugs, hallucination drugs, anticancer drugs, nicotine and tobacco, drug interaction
Weelk
11
Chemistry of the Environment
Greenhouse effect, acid rain, ozone depletion, air pollutants, hazardous waste.
Video show: "Ozone depletion"
Week 12
Energy and resources
Gasoline, diesel, natural gas, solar power, hydroelectric power, wind power
Week
13
Materials - Polymers
Polymers, Natural fibres, synthetic fibres, paints and adhesives, plastics and polymers

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Astronomy – A Short Introduction
courses.description: The course aims at providing a short introduction to some basic concepts in astronomy. Topics covered will include: Powers of Ten journey of the universe, apparent motions of celestial bodies, seasons, the Moon, eclipses, basic astronomical observation; descriptions of gravity and motions, its applications on solar system and beyond, including the phenomena of planets and small bodies, and its manifestations in space travel and popular science culture, such as exoplanets, doomsday astronomy, black holes, and cosmology. Lectures are designed not focusing on a volume of knowledge and theories, but also and phenomena to arouse students’ curiosity in how nature works, and understand our relationship with the universe. An optional star-gazing night and/or visit to Hong Kong Space Museum will be arranged. Compared with UGEB 2401 Astronomy, this course provides a shorter introduction to the essential ideas and phenomena in astronomy which students may encounter in their daily life, and focuses on arousing students’ interests in operations of modern science through lively contexts in astronomical discoveries and popular science culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Physics Majors; students in the following concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Physical Sciences; and students who have taken PHYS2401, UGEB2401, 2402 or 2510. 
Co-requisite: Courses with course code prefix as “UGFH” or “UGFN”
courses.component:
Independent Study
Lecture
Visit
Web-enhanced Teaching
courses.course_syllabus:
For the required readings by topics, please refer to the numbered items in Section 8.
Part I Survey of the universe
Powers of Ten journey of the universe [1], properties of celestial bodies and their hierarchy. This section introduces general ideas on the structure of the universe and our position in it.
Part II The sky as seen from Earth
Celestial sphere, daily motion, the sky as seen in different latitudes, yearly motion of the Sun, seasons, precession [2], the Moon, eclipses [3], angular measurement, apparent magnitudes, constellations, star-gazing, basic astronomical observation [2]. This section introduces some astronomical phenomena that are commonly encountered in daily life.
Part III Motions of celestial bodies
Kepler’s laws of planetary motion [4], gravity and motions [5], with examples in the solar system and beyond, including phenomena of planets, small bodies [9-12], and various topics on space travel and popular science culture, such as exoplanets, doomsday cosmic collisions, black holes, and cosmology [5-8, 12]. This section serves to introduce the operations of modern astronomy through lively contexts in the latest astronomical discoveries, space travel, and popular science culture.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Chemistry in the Kitchen
courses.description: The course is designed to illustrate how chemical knowledge helps demystify common phenomena in food processing, cooking and cleaning. Emphasis is given to observable changes in color, odor, taste and texture. The health aspect of chemicals encountered in the kitchen and in “health food store” will be discussed. Some of the latest technologies in cooking, cleaning and utensil materials will be introduced. The impact of cooking and cleaning methods on the environment (in terms of particulates and radiation) will be discussed. Some demonstrations will be carried out in class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for stu maj in prog by Fac of Med;not for Chem;stud in con areas of NatSciProg: AnaTestSci;or Chem Sci;students who have taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370,2380,2410 or 2440. Co-requisite:UGFH1000, UGFN1000or1001 (only appli to students admitted to 4year curr)
courses.learning_outcomes: They will learn the effects of acid/bases, reduction/oxidation, protein denaturation/degradation and chemical kinetics (e.g. cooking time/temperature) on the physical appearance and the aroma/taste of prepared foodstuff. They should be more aware of chemical safety in the kitchen, as well as the health aspects of various dishes or dietary supplements. They will become more concerned with the choice of cooking utensil materials, the energy efficiencies of cooking methods and their associated environmental issues, and the proper ways in cleaning up. The more adventurous few will be able to take advantage of the chemical knowledge acquired in modifying of perfecting traditional recipes.
courses.course_syllabus:
Chemistry Basics:
Atoms, elements & compounds
Valency, covalent bonding, ionic bonding & hydrogen bonding
Acids & bases (the pH scale)
A layman’s view of Organic chemistry
Food categories.
Bread, Cakes and Rice:
Formation of gluten
The function of leaveners: Yeast, baking soda & baking powder
Long-grain vs short-grain rice
Staling, storage & reheating.
* Genetically-modified food a godsend or evil?
Fats, Oils, Butter and Margarine:
Saturated, mono-unsaturated, poly-unsaturated fats
The olive oil myth: why is it so expensive?
Shortenings & oil-substitutes: are they suitable for daily use?
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) vs. HDL: who is the bad guy?
Deep-fat frying: what are the nasty stuff?
Anti-oxidants or preservatives? The debate continues
What is margarine? How the trans-fat emerges? A look at hydrogenation process
* Is no-fat diet good for you?
Eggs – the Natural Emulsifier:
How to keep them fresh?
Fried, scrambled, poached & hard-boiled eggs: how to avoid an ugly green yolk
Chinese century-eggs: what can we do without lead?
Custards, egg-white foams, salad dressing; Salmonellosis.
* Non-stick Teflon coating is absolutely safe.
Fruits and Vegetables:
Storage & ripening, taste & aroma, enzymatic browning; Nutrients: vitamin C & folic acid; Colorful presentation (It’s all in the pH)
* Organic farming is a hype.
* A vegetarian is a normal person.
Cuts of Meat:
Light vs. dark meat
How muscles cook?
Cooking methods for various cuts of meat: fry, roast, poach and steam
Ageing of meat & meat tenderizers
Get rid of the fishy smell in steaming fish and in your fingers.
* Shark cartilage soup is good for prevention of cancer.
* Banning live chickens import is the way to prevent the spread of bird flu in HK.
Beverages:
The bitterness & muddiness of tea & coffee
Freeze-dried & decaffeinated coffee
Soda pops: real sugar or sugar-substitutes? Are they carcinogenic?
Alcohols: the difference between ale and lager.
Wine, liquor and liqueur. Is Sake a beer or a wine?
The connoisseur: the art (or is it science) of wine tasting
Hangover. Over the limit: the breathalyzer
* Caffeine a good guy or a bad guy?
* Red wine keeps the French healthy.
Modern Cooking Methods:
The electric rice cooker: how it tells if the rice is done?
Microwave & infrared cooking: will the food glow in the dark?
Inductive cooker (safe hotpot choice): why it works best with thin iron pot?
Thermos cooking: it’s all about insulation and heat capacities of the content.
* Flameless cooking is a solution to pollution.
Cleaning Up;
Making water wetter than wet.
Hard water? Acid to the rescue
Liquid detergent vs conventional soap; Micelle formation.
Drano to clear the clogged pipes: break and burn
Mr Oven Clean to get rid of the stubborn burnt proteins
Whiter than white illusion in laundry
Dry cleaning with carbon dioxide.
* Surfactants are doing more harm than good to the society.
Some Thoughts on “Health Food”
What exactly are these stuff?
Do we really need dietary supplements?
* A silver needle is a good detector for food poisoning.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Chemistry of Food and Drinks
courses.description: Hong Kong is very famous for its superb cuisine, which is a fantastic fusion of eastern and western styles. Cooking is both an art and a science. Good tasting foods and drinks are the results of perfect matches of ingredients and cooking methods. Foods and drinks is related to chemistry closely. Having some understanding about the chemistry of the food ingredients and the various cooking methods can help appreciating the connections between science and human life. This course will discuss the Hong Kong cuisine culture from the chemistry perspective, to explain why these famous foods and drinks are so tasty and popular. Examples include Chinese rotisserie (Siu Mei), wonton noodles, steamed seafoods, stewed beef brisket, silk stocking milk tea, and century egg with pickled ginger, etc. Consuming food and soups that carry health and therapeutic values is also a unique food culture in China and Southeast Asia. The course will introduce several types of food that are traditionally considered to have some specific functions, and discuss their scientific justifications from the chemistry point of views. Besides, pre-packaged food and fast food is an important eating culture of modern urban people. Some important issues about pre-packaged food and fast food, such as food storage and packaging, uses of approved (and sometimes prohibited) food additives, alternative ingredients, and food testing, will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for Chem;Food and Nu Sci Maj;students in the concen areas of NatSci Prog: Ana and Test Sci; or Chem Sci; students taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370, 2380,2410 or 2420.Co-requisite: UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curri)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the courses, students should be able to:
identify the connections between science and culture.
interpret the traditional and local food culture from the scientific perspectives.
explain the chemistry of the basic constituents of foods and drinks.
explain the chemical changes involved in the various cooking methods.
identify the scientifc justifications of some traditional function foods.
evaluate the commonly claimed advantages of functional foods and therapeutic diets from the science perspectives.
recognize the applications of modern science and technology in improving food productions and food safety.
describe the principles of some common food packaging methods.
acquire basic scientific grounds to judge about the validity of some misconceptions and common believes about foods and health.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction
Some Highlights of the Hong Kong, Chinese, and Asian Cuisine Culture
Highlights of some major differences between the Eastern and Western food cultures.
Local foods that have a long tradition / long history, especially
Foods that have regional causes
Foods that have therapeutic values
Brief introductions of the topics to be covered in this course
Week 2: Meats in Chinese Dishes
Meats in Chinese dishes: recipes and preparation techniques
(e.g. Guangdong roasted meat / Chinese rotisserie (Siu Mei), stewed beef brisket)
Meat types and the common cooking methods
Chemical interpretation of the preparation methods
Flavors and aromas in meat cooking
Meat tenderizing in Chinese recipes
Week 3: Carbos in Chinese Food (Rice, Congee, Vermicelli, and Noodles)
Rice – the main source of energy for Southeast Asians
(The chemistry of the constituents of rice and cooking methods)
The chemistry of carbohydrates
Brown rice
vs.
white rice, which one is healthier from the chemistry perspectives
Vermicelli and Noodles – differneces in texture and ingredients
Chinese noodles preparation (using lye water)
Week 4: Seafoods: Fresh and Dry
Types of fresh seafood loved by Hong Kong people
Constituents and nutrition of seafoods
Omega-3
Safety of seafood products (marine toxins and heavy metals)
Collagen from dry seafood (the chemistry of collagen)
Nutrition values of shark fin soup
Week 5: Chinese Soups and Health
The soup eating habits of Chinese families
Long-simmered Chinese soups:
Recipes, nutrition and functions - examples
Soups with medicinal herbs
Bird’s nest soup
Shark cartilage
Week 6: Therapeutic Diets / Asian Spices & Chinese Herbs
Medicinal herbs in Chinese dishes
Ginkgo
The therapeutic values of spices used in Chinese dishes
Cinnamon
Chinese Star Anise
Curry
(ingredients and functions)
Week 7: Asian and Chinese Spicy Foods / Ginger in Chinese Dishes
People in South-West and South-Central China, and in Southeast Asia like “Hot and Spicy” Foods
The chemistry of “Hot and Spicy”
The physiology of Hot and Spicy Foods
Ginger in Chinese dishes
For steamed fish
Pig’s trotters in ginger and sweetened vinegar
The chemistry and therapeutic values of ginger
White and black pepper in Asian dishes
(ingredients and therapeutic functions)
Week 8: Beverages in Traditional and Modern Culture
Chinese Huangjiu (yellow wine) and Baijiu (white wine): preparation methods and ingredients
Chinese tea: processing methods, compositions and the claimed health functions
100% HK: Silk stocking milk tea (the chemistry interpretation of the preparation)
Soft drinks & fruit juices (natural
vs.
artificial)
Chemical synthesis in food industry
Isotonic sport drinks
(composition and chemistry)
Week 9: Chinese Condiment and Chinese Preserved Foods
Soy sauce and vinegar – two great products from biochemical reactions
Scientific methods for analyzing the flavor compounds in soy sauce
Other fermented foods in Chinese / Asian dishes
The chemistry of the traditional ways of food preservations
Preserved foods and health: Cantonese-style salted fishes and Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
Week 10: Myths and Misconceptions in Chinese Food Culture
The chemistry of Century eggs
“
Like nourishes like
” in traditional Chinese therapeutic diets
Incompatible foods
Kidney stones and daily consumption of tea
Week 11: Foods for People in the Plastic Age (Packaged Foods)
The Chemistry of food packaging
Carbonated soft drinks
Vitasoy
Potato chips
Pre-packed meats in supermarkets
Safety concerns about food packaging materials
Synthetic/alternative ingredients of food
(e.g. fat substitutes for snacks)
Week 12: Food Incidents, Food Safety and Food Testing
The importance of food safety
Well-known examples of food incidents, and the importance of reliable food testing methods
Melamine in milk
Malachite green in fishes
Plasticizers (DEHP) in bubble tea
Ciguatera in deep-water fishes
Week 13: Food Productions (For Today and Tomorrow)
Chemicals in agricultural industry
(fertilizers and pesticides)
Growth enhancers in animal farming industry
Risks associated with agrochemicals
Organic foods
GM foods
