courses.description: The course UGEB2460 is an "appreciation" course on mathematics. As such, its emphasis is on the "appreciation" aspect and not on the detailed technicalities of mathematics.The course is designed for all students, except those majoring in Mathematics, Mathematics Education and Mathematics and Information Engineering.In this course, we outline through everyday examples how mathematicsshapes our contemporary world. These examples are based on simple, yet clever ideas which can be explained to the widest audience.It is hoped that through the course, students can get a feeling of "how mathematics works". We will look at examples from mobile phones, from GPS, computer graphics, ATM machines, voting systems, forensic detection of accounting forgery, computer graphics, Escher's paintings, quasicrystals, world atlas constructions etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for MATH; MIEG; BMED Majors; and students in the following concentration areas of NSCI Programme: Data Science, Mathematical Sciences.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Appreciate the historical background, in specific examples of key mathematical ideas which are related to innovative objects used by the human society in the last four centuries.
Comprehend, if deemed possible, some of these mathematical ideas behind many math-related objects in our daily life.
Recognize and analyze mathematical ideas in some other gadgets motivated by mathematics.
Acquire a rudimentary knowledge of artistic and mathematical vocabulary which could then be applied to discuss (both orally and in writing) ideas presented in the course Evaluate the importance of the role which mathematics plays in our daily life.
courses.course_syllabus:
The concept and its evolution from the Antiquity to present day
Different types of numbers and their applications
How clever manipulation leads to better applications – examples from arithmetic and geometry etc.
Simple counting
Rubber Sheet Geometry
Logic and why it is useful in the internet world
Rethinking why we learn mathematics

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Perspectives in Risk Management and Modern Society
courses.description: Risk management is without doubt one of the most important issues in various aspects of the modern society. Quantifying risk management is not only a management tool, but is also a scientific activity. This course aims at introducing the role of risk management in modern society. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the role of risk management and its impact on every day life both at personal and institutional level.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for RMSC,STAT,QFRM,CDAS Majors, students in Data Science or Mathematical Sciences concentration areas of Natural Sciences Programme, and students who have taken RMSC2001
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.academic_org: Dept of Stat and Data Sci
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course develops the students' basic concepts of risk management in broad terms. After the course, the students are expected:

to understand the evolution of risk management science in the modem society (T1, T2, T6).

to identify and evaluate potential risks in daily life (T1, T3).

to develop a systematic, although conceptual, approach in handling various types of risks in life and work (T3, T4, T5).

to appreciate the need of continuous development in risk management techniques to adapt the ever-changing economical and social environment (T1, T6).
Topics:
T1: Basic risk management concepts: classification, identification, evaluation.
T2: Economic theories underlying risk management.
T3: Risk management in daily life: e.g. health risk and retirement risk.
T4: Risk management using insurance.
T5: Risk management using financial derivatives.
T6: A case study of risk management evolution in modern society.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risks and risk measures from ascientific perspective. The course will discuss on various roles that risk plays in our modern society. Topics include:
1. The evolution and development of modern risk management practice. The shift in philosophy from solely insurance buying for pure risks to integrated risk management for much broader scope of risks. Related concepts, such as perils, hazards and adverse selection, will also be discussed through various real life examples;
2. Classification and identification of risks. We shall use daily life examples to arouse students’ sensitivity to risks.
3. Risk management techniques such as risk avoidance, risk control and risk financing.
4. Basic principles underlying insurance. We shall introduce the development of this traditional risk management tool for new and complicated types of risks, such as terrorism and natural disasters.
5. Banking industry experienced significant and continuous changes in their ways of handling risks. We shall discuss the history of this evolution as an example of the development of risk management concept.
6. Case studies (e.g. SARS, Hurricane Katrina, 911 attacks) will be discussed in order to illustrate the risks in different aspects of our life and the appropriate tools to manage it.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Human Evolution
courses.description: (UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810.)  What does it mean to be human? Where did we come from? Where are we going? This course investigates long-term evolutionary perspectives on the human species. The basics of evolution and natural selection as scientific theories are clearly set out and examined, and common misconceptions discussed. Evidence for the evolution of mammals and primates is reviewed and discussed, and the common characteristics of these species are highlighted, demonstrating the connections between humans and other forms of life. The course covers what we know about human ancestors and the evolution of modern humans. Students are introduced to the wide range of human adaptations to local conditions across contemporary cultures and the variety of relationships that human populations have with the environment. Students are encouraged to use the knowledge they have acquired to ask: are these relationships always sustainable? Looking to the future: what are our responsibilities both to future generations of humans and towards other species with which we share our world? This course aims to give students an understanding and appreciation of evolutionary perspectives on the place of humans in the world, the variety of contemporary human societies, and a broad perspective on the complexity of the relationship between humans, the environment and other species.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2810. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_attributes: Shared Learning Activities with ANTH5810
courses.learning_outcomes:
In this course students learn about the nature of scientific theories and their development, as well as the use of evidence in evaluating hypotheses. Students are also exposed to the potential for misunderstandings of scientific theory and the distinction between fact and value. Comparative abilities are emphasised through reviewing common features of the life-course of a variety of animals and the influence of animal habitats, with particular focus on closely related primate species.
The history of human evolution is introduced to students, focussing on the emergence of universal capacities such as language, technology, art and culture. Students are encouraged to learn about and appreciate the variety of human cultures and the flexibility of humans in adapting to local environments. A comparative perspective on human culture is encouraged through a focus on the common subsistence needs of all humans, and the variety of practices by which these needs are met.
Students are exposed to a wide perspective on the place of the human species in the world. They are encouraged to exercise long-term evaluations of, and exercise a sense of judgement about the impact and sustainability of human action, both in relation to the environment and other species as well as future generations of the human species. Students are thus encouraged to think about their own place in society.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Deciphering the Past: Culture, Archaeology and Science
courses.description: (UGEB2505 is double-coded with ANTH2740.) How we understand the past defines the way how we understand our current situation. Archaeology is a dynamic discipline that has tremendously expanded our knowledge about the past, but this subject is not just about digging and doing fieldwork. A wide range of new techniques (e.g., metallurgy, zoology, and 3d stimulation) and research methods have been incorporated into current archaeological research, and eventually transformed the understanding of ourselves and our culture in many ways. This course provides a general introduction in terms of two specific domains: 1) basic archaeological science that changed the research paradigm of human culture and history; 2) an overall history about ancient technology illustrated by new research techniques to explain how this modern world took shape. Moreover, this course provides hands-on practice to cultivate students’ cross-disciplinary research skills and prepare them for the arrival of a new, digitalized research era.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEB2505 is double-coded with ANTH2740. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2740. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.component:
Field Studies/Field-trip
Laboratory
Lecture
Project
Interactive Tutorial
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction
What is archaeological science and the archaeological way of the thinking?
No reading for this week
Week 2: Can we study aliens in the past?
What is the philosophy of science and pseudoarchaeology?
Week 3: Truth and fallacies in numbers
An introduction to quantitative research and sampling in archaeology
Week 4: Deciphering the secret of our meat
A basic introduction to zooarchaeology
Week 5: Deciphering the secret of our staple foods
A basic introduction to archaeobotany and early globalization of food
Week 6: Deciphering the secret of ancient space and landscape
A basic introduction to spatial technology and satellite images to understand how people lived in the past
Week 7: Deciphering the microscopic world
A basic introduction to microscopic techniques and chemical analytical methods
Week 8: Mid-term exam
Week 9: Deciphering the ancient industrial world
A basic introduction to mineral exploitation and difference between ancient and modern mining
Week 10: Deciphering the secrete of ancient ceramics
A basic introduction to the manufacturing techniques of ceramics and impacts of
pyrotechnology in human history
Week 11: Deciphering the secrete of ancient bronze
A basic introduction to ancient bronze technology and formation of early bronze trade
Week 12: Deciphering the secrete of ancient metal objects (gold, silver and iron)
A basic introduction to other ancient meter technology (e.g., iron) and early commodity exchange
Week 13: Can scientific methodology help save the past?
A basic introduction to techniques in cultural heritage conservation

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: The Stars and Our Lives
courses.description: The course aims at studying the human exploration of astronomical phenomena in the history, thereby disclosing the interplay between astronomical activities and the cultural, social, and scientific aspects of human lives, as well as the deep and authentic relation between the celestial bodies and the lives on earth. Topics include: astronomical traditions of ancient civilizations and their social functions, astronomical phenomena found in ancient books, literature, myths and their scientific explanations; the impact of scientific revolutions in the Renaissance and the 20th century on our views of the universe, human thought and modern civilization, the influence of cosmic events on the lives on earth, the quest for extraterrestrial lives. Star-gazing activity is included to enhance students’ interest. The course is designed to help students with little or no science background gain intellectual perspectives on the interplay between science and culture, and our subtle relation with the universe.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for majors in Fac. of Erg. or Fac. of Sci., IDA+X Double Maj.Prog., ASEI+X Double Maj.Prog., MASE+X Double Maj.Prog., MIEG,BMED,QFRM Majors & students who have taken PHYS2401,UGEB2401,2402 or 2411.
Co-req.: Any course with “UGFH” / “UGFN” as prefix.
courses.learning_outcomes:

Students gain a understanding of the interplay between the astronomical traditions of ancient civilizations and their cultural and social backgrounds.

Students gain intellectual perspectives on the history of science, the interplay between science and other human activities, and the impacts of science on human thoughts and modern civilization.

Students acquire some basic knowledge in astronomy, gain a understanding of our position in the universe, and our deep and subtle relation with various cosmic events.

Students gain intellectual perspectives on the modern astronomical discoveries and their implications on our views of the universe.

Arouse students' curiosity and stimulate their imagination on the mysteries of the universe, thus providing some motivation for life-long learning.

Students gain hands-on experience in star-gazing and he motivated to learn more about the cultural and historical aspects of science.
courses.course_syllabus:

Cosmic tour: A virtual journey to the cosmos using the 'Powers of Ten' approach. Our position in the universe and the hierarchy of celestial bodies
[l,
2,
3].

The sky and our lives: Common astronomical phenomena such as the apparent motions of the stars and the sun, seasons, lunar phases, eclipses, precession, their scientific explanations and relations to our lives, star-gazing and amateur astronomy, western astronomical traditions and mythology of the night sky
[l,
2, 4]

Chinese astronomical tradition and culture: Chinese astronomical traditions throughout the history, its cultural, social, and astrological origins, the social functions of astronomical activities, astronomical phenomena in ancient books, literature and their implications, the scientific and non-scientific aspects of Chinese astronomical traditions [1,
5, 6]

Western astronomy and the modern world: Ancient Greeks astronomy, Medieval Islamic astronomy and their scientific basis, Renaissance astronomy and its impacts on science, scientific methods, human thought, and modern civilization; revolution in physics and astronomy in the 20th century and its influence on our views of the universe; modern cosmology from the physical science points of view [1, 2, 7, 8]

Cosmic events and our destiny: Cosmic events including Big Bang, the evolution of stars, impacts of asteroids and comets on earth, and their relations to the origin, evolution and destruction of lives on the Earth
[l, 3,
8,
9]

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Games and Strategic Thinking
courses.description: The aim of this course is to study games and strategies from the mathematical perspective. We investigate the manner in which rational people interact when there are competitions. This applies to parlour games and more importantly to economy, social psychology, politics and business. We will introduce the great discoveries of Von Neumann and Nash, and discuss their impact on society. Also, we will use examples of various types of games to illustrate how some basic mathematical methods can lead to optimal strategies for decision making.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for MATH; MIEG; BMED; students in the concen areas of Natural Sci Prog: Data Sci; or Mathematical Sci; and students taken ECON3160 or MATH4250.Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
We expect students to learn how to formulate real life problems that involve strategic interaction as mathematical games, and to be able to use the appropriate mathematical tools to study such games. We expect students to be able to:
Understand the concepts of a game, such as players, positions, moves, strategies, information, rationality, game trees, outcomes, payoffs, zero-sum and non-zero-sum games, Pareto optimality, equilibrium, sequential games, cooperative games.
Formulate and solve simple matrix games, and to use them for investigating practical situations.
Appreciate how game theory may be applied in other fields of knowledge, such as economics, political science, biology, and how it may be applied in decision making processes, such as auction pricing, cost allocations problems, military planning, diplomacy.
Be aware of the aims, scope and limitations of game theory.
courses.course_syllabus:
Core content:
Basic concepts: players, positions, moves, strategies, information, rationality, game trees, outcomes, payoffs, zero-sum and non-zero-sum games.
Equilibrium concepts: Solution to a game, Pareto optimality, dominant strategy equilibrium, Nash equilibrium, Prisoner Dilemma.
Two-person zero-sum games, two-person non-zero sum games, and their applications.
Selected topics:
Sequential games; complete and incomplete information games and their applications.
Cooperative and non-cooperative games, N-person games and their applications.
Combinatorial games.
Relevant mathematical tools, such as matrices, probability and graphs, will be developed in the course.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Perspectives in Meteorology

meetings.instructor:
Professor LEUNG Wing Mo, 
Professor LI Ping Wah

courses.description: An introduction to meteorological phenomena and mechanisms. This course aims at a non-mathematical exposition of the central ideas of meteorological study. The interaction between the weather, climate and human activities will also be discussed, including how the extreme weather and climate information could be used in adaptation, mitigation, and sustainability research and applications. Topics include atmospheric phenomena such as general circulation, storms, typhoons and other weather-related disasters, forecasting, oceanic processes, El Nino and La Nina, global climate changes and sustainable development. The relevant United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including, SDG#7 Affordable and clean energy, SDG#9 Industry, Innovation and infrastructure, SDG#11 Sustainable cities and communities, SDG#13 Climate action, SDG#14 Life below water, SDG#15 Life on Land, and SDG#17 Partnerships will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Physics,Earth System Science, Earth and Environmental Sciences Majors, students in Physical Sciences concentration of Natural Sciences Programme
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
SDG-GE #17 Partnerships for the Goals
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to:
- gain a perspectives of scientific approach in solving problems and how the real systems such as weather and climate can be tackled by scientific methods,
- acquire some knowledge about the mechanisms of various phenomena in meteorology,
- develop a perspective of the relations between weather/climate and the human society,
- develop a perspective of how the environment of the earth is influenced by the interaction between different parts of Nature and human activities,
- develop a perspective of how knowledge can be gained, how scientific way can help to analyse and make forecast among uncertainties,
- be aware of the global efforts in implementing various meteorology-related actions and services in contributing to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
- be aware of the critical role of human race in the future of the earth.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week
1 Introduction to the Atmosphere
Composition, greenhouse effect, structure, evolution
Week
2 Solar radiation and energy balance
The sun, seasons, energy balance and temperature
Week
3-4 Moisture, clouds, and precipitation
Humidity and saturation, stability, clouds, precipitation
Week
4-5 Wind and atmospheric circulation
Air pressure, winds, measurement, global circulation, air masses, fronts, jet streams,
Week
5&6 Thunder storm and tornadoes, tropical cyclones
Formation, structure, tracking, power
Week
7&8 Planetary atmospheres and weathers
Weather and climate on Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, . . .
Week
9-10 Lightning and optical phenomena
Formation of lightning, rainbow, halo, aurora, green flash, . . .
Week
10-11 Weather
forecasting
Forecasting and modeling, services and operations of Hong Kong Observatory
Week
11-12
Global climate change
Past climates, mechanisms, methods to know about the past climates, case studies: El Nino and La Nina, . . .
Week
12-14 Global crisis
- 
ozone depletion, global warming and sustainability
Ozone hole, effect on human, public policy, sustainability, current events and future prospects; Runaway greenhouse effect, evidence of global warming, effect of global warming, the Paris Agreement, Sendai Framework, ethical considerations of environmental and climate change issues, other hypotheses
Many of the above topics are related to various Goal of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, including SDG#7, #9, #11, #13, #14, #15 and #17.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Materials Science for a Sustainable World
courses.description: This course offers a friendly introduction to materials science, highlighting technologies from constructing a lightweight supersonic aircraft to fabricating a computer microprocessor, and its connection to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Designed for students with little science background, it covers essential topics like metals, polymers, ceramics, composites, and semiconductors. Key topics include their basic properties, structures, processing techniques, applications, and those of the modern advanced materials, all in connection with pressing global issues. SDGs include (1) materials and technology for achieving affordable and clean energy such as solar cells and fuel cells (SDG-7), (2) the materials in sustainable technology industry, such as bioplastic and hydrogen energy (SDG-9), (3) on the potential of employing biodegradable materials, improving material supply chains of plastic and electronic devices, and developing end-users strategies for sustainable consumptions and productions (SDG-12), (4) global collaborations to address issues related to the uneven distribution of material resources, processing technologies, and capital (SDG-10 and -17), (5) the impact of plastic and electronic devices on lives and environment (SDG-14 and -15). A system perspective with relevant cases will be employed to explore the roles of materials science in sustainability issues, its economic, social and environmental implications, and relevance to different social groups (e.g. local and global communities, companies, government, NGOs). Students will also have a chance to reflect on their own roles.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for PHYS, CHEM Majors; NSCI major concentrations in Analytical and Testing Sciences, Chemical Sciences, or Physical Sciences.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #12 Responsible Consumption and Production
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to:
acquire some knowledge to classify different types of materials.
explain and compare various approaches in materials investigations.
be able to understand why some materials can be used and some cannot.
develop a perspective of relating materials to human development and society, and establish its relationship with SDGs such as sustainable energy, reduced equalities, partnerships for goals, consumption and production, and life on land (and below water).
recognize and evaluate environmental issues while using or disposing of materials and how these are related to the SDGs.
list what sorts of materials are being used in some hi-tech applications, including the technology used in sustainable energy system
relate and synthesis the insights learnt from material science with the student’s own role, own interests and discipline (major study programme) on the issues related to SDGs
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction:
Differences between pure and applied sciences, materials science and engineering
History of materials, periodic tables and natural elements. Classification of materials
Metals:
History of metals, structures and properties of metals
Polycrystalline and single crystalline
Metallography: methods of studying metals. Phase diagrams, mechanical properties
Crystal defects and dislocations
Specific metal and rare materials used in sustainable energy systems (e.g. Nickel and Platinum for hydrogen production and use).
The industry and value-chain involved, and their geographic distribution and its implication on the equalities between countries and the need for global collaboration. (SDGs: Affordable and Clean Energy, Reducing Inequality, Partnerships for the Goals)
The role of specific metals in the sustainable technology industry (SDG: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure)
Polymers:
Polymers and environment
Dioxin. Types of polymers: natural polymers and synthetic polymers. General properties
Thermoplastics, thermosets and elastomers. Rubber and vulcanization
Forming processes in polymers productions
Recycling. The current production and consumption of plastic and its impact on ecosystem and marine life (related to SDGs Life on Land and Life below water)
Plastic made of biodegradable material and their use in daily life (e.g. cosmetics), and how the new sustainable technology industry harnesses such biodegradable material with real examples (SDG: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure)
Ceramics:
Definitions of ceramics. Comparison of ceramics to other materials
Traditional and advanced ceramics, civilization and human development
Structures. Properties and applications
Ceramics used in automobiles and space shuttles
The environmental impact of ceramic material and its use for thermal heat storage (related to the SDG of Affordable and Clean Energy, Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure)
Composites
Definitions. Properties and applications
Metal-based and ceramic-based composites. Parts in automobiles
Semi-conductors
Electrons and holes carriers. Electrical behaviors Optical behaviors. Bands structures
Products and applications such as electronic devices and solar panels
Energy use in and consumption behaviour on electronic devices (SDGs on “Clean and Affordable energy” (solar panel), “Responsible Consumption and Production”)
Rare materials used for producing semi-conductors. The industry and value-chain involved, and their geographic distribution and its implication on the equalities between countries and the need for global collaboration (SDG: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure, Reducing Inequality, Partnerships for the Goals)

Course and teaching evaluation survey will be conducted in the second last week of the course.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Perspectives in Medical Sciences
courses.description: This course aims to provide the structural and functional bases as well as the new advances at the molecular and cellular levels for the understanding of how our body works and adapts to changes in the internal and external environment, such as imbalance of chemicals and hormones, extreme alterations in temperature and pressure, as well as after mutation and during aging. In addition, development of knowledge about the causes of disorders in the body and what drugs and new therapeutic approaches can be used for treatment are also areas of focus.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:
Describe the basic human body structures, their functions, and related clinical issues.
Describe how the body regulates itself to encounter both internal and external changes and the consequences if it fails to do so.
Write the relevance and importance of advances in medical sciences to the well-being of mankind.
Read, analyse, and criticise both the general and research articles related to the human body and health issues.
Use different resources such as library and internet to search for body and health related information.
Comment and critique on the controversies and ethical issues that come with the latest advances in medical sciences.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course is roughly divided into two blocks with the first half mainly introducing the perpetuation of life and maintenance of the life processes and the second half emphasizing more on the health issues and physical disorders. All lectures will be conducted by teachers from the School of Biomedical Sciences. Each lecture will start by introducing some basic knowledge of the topics and then move into relating its relevance to the understanding of disease conditions. The impact of some latest advances in medical sciences on mankind will also be discussed.
Perpetuation of life and maintenance of life processes
Medical sciences help us to better understand the upholding of the healthy, normal status of our body. The seven lectures in this area will illustrate the general anatomical and physiological concepts for understanding the sophisticated yet highly coordinated mechanisms involved in the conception of life and normal functioning of the human body.
Topics include:
Topics
Learning Contents
Fertility and infertility
Reproduction is essential for the continued existence of a species. This lecture provides a brief overview on the physiological control of gamete production in men and women, and various factors that determine fertility and contribute towards infertility. Various methods of contraception and how they work will be introduced.
Miracle of life
This lecture gives an account of the human reproductive system and the prenatal development of the human embryo inside mother’s womb. It covers the human embryonic development starting from a fertilized egg which then grows to a cluster of cells and gradually changes and develops into a fetus during pregnancy. It also touches on test-tube baby and techniques for assisted reproduction.
A beautiful mind: wonders of the brain
Our memories, emotions and actions determine who we are. All these are functions of the brain and this lecture will reveal the important features of this mysterious anatomical structure.
Body composition and body fluid
Water makes up of about 60% of our body weight. The various functions of water in humans and the physiological regulation of total body water volume and its contents will be outlined.
Cardiovascular diseases and treatments
Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and ischemic heart diseases are the most prevalent medical conditions in the Western society. This lecture will briefly cover the organization and physiological control of the cardiovascular system. Besides, the common causes of cardiovascular diseases and the basis of current drug treatments will be introduced.
Wireless control in our body: hormones
Hormones are chemical messengers which act as wireless control of life processes in the human body. Travelling from the site of synthesis to distant target tissues or organs via the bloodstream, hormones can exert widespread influences over a long distance. In this lecture, the control and function of various endocrine systems, as well as the causes and symptoms of common endocrine diseases will be discussed.
Life at the extremes
Majority of the human population live in areas close to sea level. The body is highly adapted to the air pressure and oxygen content at this altitude. When a lowlander ascends, the pressure becomes lower and oxygen content reduces, body has to adapt to this new environment. A highlander lives at high altitude for thousands of years and their physical performance is much better than a fully adapted lowlander. The physiological and genetic adaptation process will be described.
Health issues and
physical disorders
An understanding of the body defense system and disease mechanisms is important for the maintenance of health and the choice of effective treatments. The pathophysiological mechanisms involved in physical disorders induced by deterioration of normal physiological functions or by exposure of the body to foreign substances/organisms will be examined.
Topics included:
Topics
Learning Contents
Body defense
Our defense system is a body-wide network consisting of organs, tissues, cells, and small molecules that work together to fight against “foreign” invaders and different kinds of stressors. This lecture aims to introduce the mechanism of body defense and response to infection as one source of body immune reaction. The common hospital-acquired infections and epidemiology will also be discussed.
Targeting our genes
In human, genetic codes are stored in DNA. The human genome contains 3 billion base pairs of nucleotides. Any mutations in the DNA sequence may lead to genetic diseases. The goal of the Human Genome Project is to determine the complete DNA sequence in human. In this lecture, basic knowledge of genetics as well as the causes of genetic diseases will be introduced, and the importance of the human genome project in the study of genetic diseases will be discussed. Enormous progress on genome editing has been made in the past few years. The genome editing tools and prospects of this technology will also be discussed.
Avoiding the top killer - cancer
Cancer is a major killer disease that has long haunted mankind. Carcinogenesis refers to the development of cancerous cells from normal cells. In this lecture, different causes of carcinogenesis and the impact of human activities on the development of cancer will be discussed.
Drugs that we take
This lecture aims to provide students with a basic understanding on what are drugs, how they are discovered, and how they work. General pharmacological principles which are important for understanding the proper use of drugs as medicines will be discussed. Drug abuse and its harmful effects will also be described.
Healthy aging
Aging is a natural process that causes a gradual slowdown of body function and increases the risk of developing diseases. This lecture will explore the effects of aging on different body functions and discuss the strategies that can be used to delay the process of aging and prepare the body and mind for a healthy aging.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Perspectives in Clinical Sciences
courses.description: Health is one of the most important things of our life. Good health allows us to live a full life and free us up to engage in daily activities. However, emerging diseases, such as genetic disorders at birth, highly infectious viral diseases, and aging-related degenerative disorders, can cause significant physical and mental suffering, even premature death.In this course, students are introduced to various types of common diseases that can be encountered in daily life in Hong Kong. The medical knowledge and the physiological mechanisms behind the development of these diseases can provide students a thorough understanding of the functional changes of our body, which will help them make informed decisions about their lifestyle choices and proactively take preventive measures to protect themselves from these diseases.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• recognize the major causes of common diseases in Hong Kong.
• describe the key strategies for disease prevention.
• understand the most up-to-date technologies in disease diagnosis and treatment.
• integrate and apply the medical knowledge learned from the lectures with real-life scenarios.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Outline:
Four major areas will be covered in this course. Three selected topics of interest will be given under a major area, and each one of them both from a scientific perspective and a clinical perspective.
Areas
Topics
Lecture Contents
Molecular coding of life
Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests
Science: Genetic codes and genetic diseases.
Clinical: Clinical considerations and approaches of prenatal diagnosis.
Stem cells and tissue regeneration
Science: Different types of stem cells and their differentiation potentials.
Clinical: Potential medical applications of stem cells.
Sense and sensibility
Science: A look at the human body: the five senses.
Clinical: Common problems in development.
Growing up
Allergy
Science: The immune system in our body.
Clinical: Common types of allergy in Hong Kong and their treatment.
Obesity
Science: Causes and health risks associated with obesity.
Clinical: Obesity: What should patients and health providers do?
Gastric problems
Science: Gastric acid secretion: principles and regulation.
Clinical: Common upper digestive diseases.
The invaders
Hepatitis B and liver cancer
Science:
Cell cycle, apoptosis and cancer.
Clinical:
The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of hepatitis B infection.
Influenza
Science:
Biology of the influenza virus.
Clinical:
The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of influenza.
HIV and AIDS
Science:
Biology of human immunodeficiency virus.
Clinical:
HIV: from science to medicine.
Growing old
Arthritis
Science: Purine degradation and gouty arthristis.
Clinical: Diagnosis and management of arthritis.
Osteoporosis
Science: Bone metabolism and calcium balance.
Clinical: Osteoporosis: epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment.
Alzhemier's disease
Science: The human nervous system.
Clinical: Pathology of Alzheimer's disease and their treatment.
Course Details and References:
A.
Molecular coding of life
The development from a fertilized egg to a normal functioning human being is a miraculous process. All animals begin life as a fertilized egg. After several round of cell division, the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo, and then a fetus. During development, stem cells can differentiate into different types of cells in our body. Each cell inherits the same set of DNA, but only selected genes are activated. However, any error in the genetic code will result in defects and pathological changes. Currently, prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests are employed to detect these defects. With the diagnosis of such defects, we could devise therapeutic interventions or other treatment regimens to minimize the impacts of these defects. Besides genetic diseases, some common problems might also arise during childhood development, like hearing and speech impairment, visual impairment, delay for motor skills, and mental retardation.
1. 
Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests
The genetic code is hidden in DNA. The genetic information stored in the DNA sequence is transferred through mRNA and then finally to proteins. When there are mutations in the DNA sequences, genetic diseases may arise. Prenatal diagnosis is very important in increasing the chance of delivering a healthy baby.
2. 
Stem cells and tissue regeneration
The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to Sir John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent stem cells. This discovery is an important breakthrough in medicinal research. In this lecture, the definition and characteristics of stem cells will be introduced. Methods for stem cell preparation and the potential applications of stem cells for medical therapy will be explained. Current problems and ethical issues on stem cell usage will be discussed.
3. 
Sense and sensibility
The molecular and cellular basis of different sensation will be introduced. Common sensory disorders and the effects on childhood development will be explained. Current advances in diagnosis and treatment will be discussed.
B
.
Growing up
The immune system in our body helps to protect us against disease by identifying and killing any pathogens from entering the body. However, over-reactivity of this life-saving system will cause allergy that will make troubles for us. Allergic diseases that are commonly found in Hong Kong, like rhinitis and asthma, will be introduced.
Beside allergic diseases, other problems may arise when we grow up from childhood and enter into adulthood. In the past, under-nutrition is a problem in many parts of the world. Nowadays, the problems of over-nutrition and unbalanced diet are becoming more serious in many countries.
Coupled with the lack of exercise, obesity is a common problem among many working adults in Kong Kong. Also, a stressful working environment together with the bacterial infection has made gastric problems commonplace in Hong Kong. If we continue to neglect the warning signals from our bodies, we may finally suffer from lethal organ failure.
1. 
Allergy
The immune system protects us against disease by killing the pathogens that enter our body. Disorders of immune system occur when the immune response is hypersensitive, or lacking. Allergy is an immune response excited by allergens. Allergens that are commonly found in Hong Kong include house dust mite, cockroaches, and house moulds.
2
.
Obesity
This topic will discuss diet, energy balance, healthy body weight, life styles, genetics and environmental factors in relation to overweight and obesity. It will also emphasize how obesity increases the risk of chronic diseases. The methods to treat obesity will be briefly introduced, including dietary intervention, behavior modification, medications and surgery.
3. 
Gastric problems
The Nobel Prize in Physiology & Medicine for 2005 was awarded to Barry J. Marshall and J. Robin Warren for establishment of the linkage between
Helicobacter pylori
and gastric diseases. The bacteria colonized in the stomach induce many changes in gastric secretion. This topic will address the basic science and clinical manifestation of gastric diseases.
C.
The invaders
The human race is in a state of constant battle with our environment. This struggle for survival includes the fight against microorganisms in the environment. In the past, bacterial infections caused much mortality and morbidity to the human race. With the development of antibiotics, this problem is now under control. However, we are less successful in the development of effective anti-viral drugs. Thus, viral infection has become a serious problem. In this part, three viral infected diseases will be introduced. These include influenza (caused by influenza virus), hepatitis B (caused by hepatitis B virus), and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (caused by human immunodeficiency virus).
1. 
Hepatitis B and liver cancer
In Hong Kong, it was estimated that about 10% of the whole population are hepatitis B carriers. The long-term consequences of chronic viral hepatitis infection include liver cancer, chronic liver diseases and cirrhosis. Local studies showed that approximately 80% of patients with liver cancer were hepatitis B carriers. In this module, the relationship between hepatitis B virus and liver diseases will be explored.
2. 
Influenza
The annual epidemic and the potential threat of a pandemic render influenza a major infectious disease in the world. Effective control of influenza entails a combination of good sanitary habits and the employment of effective vaccines, diagnostic tests and antiviral drugs.
3. 
HIV and AIDS
Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. According to the statistics from the World Health Organization, AIDS accounts for the highest number of deaths in the world. In this module, the structure and organization of HIV, the route of transmission of AIDS, as well as the diagnosis and therapy of AIDS will be discussed.
D.
Growing old
Aging is a natural process of all human beings. Associated with aging, many physiological aspects of the body would start to deteriorate. These include the deterioration of joint functions (which will lead to arthritis), bone functions (which will lead to the development of osteoporosis), and brain functions (which will lead to the development of Alzheimer’s disease). The proper management of these conditions is a concern for the aging population.
1. 
Arthritis
Arthritis is a major burden of mobility for the elderly. The development of arthritis is a multifactorial process. This topic will introduce the basic science and the clinical treatment for the disease.
2. 
Osteoporosis
Osteoporosis is one of the most common health problems among the elderly, characterized by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissues leading to increased bone fragility and fracture risk. In this topic, the causes, preventive measurements and treatments of osteoporosis will be discussed.
3. 
Alzheimer’s disease
The molecular basis of interneuron communication (neurotransmission) will be introduced. Clinical signs and problems of the aged brain will be explained. Advances in understanding and treatment of Alzheimer’s disease will be discussed.

courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts in Chinese medicine to students who are interested in a general understanding of the basic theories, working principles, methods for health preservation and disease healing in Chinese medicine. The course comprises an introduction to the five key areas in Chinese medicine including the basic theories, methods of diagnosis and treatment, acupuncture & moxibustion, Chinese medicinal materials, and Chinese herbal formulary. This general education module will also include some practical tutorials to demonstrate diagnostic methods, and classic treatments, which include tongue observation, pulse taking, acupuncture and cupping. The medium of instruction for the course is English.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Chinese Medicine Majors; and students who have taken UGEA1881.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.component:
Discussion
Field Studies/Field-trip
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
courses.course_syllabus:
Brief history and characteristics of Chinese medicine
Philosophies of Chinese medicine: the Yin-Yang and Five Elements theories
The internal organs: The five visceral and six bowel organs
The vital substances: Qi, blood and body fluids
The aetiology of disease from Chinese medicine’s perspective
Diagnostics in Chinese medicine
Tutorial in Chinese medical diagnosis
General introduction to acupuncture and moxibustion
Tutorial in acupuncture and moxibustion
Fundamental knowledge of Chinese medicinal herbs
(1) Brief history
(2) General properties of medicinal herbs
(3) Processing of medicinal herbs
(4) General rules of usage
Medicinal materials in common use
(1) Plant drugs, Animal drugs and Mineral drugs
(2) Therapeutic properties of Chinese medicinal herbs
Herbal formulas
(1) Principles of combination of herbal ingredients
(2) Examples of medicinal formulas
13. Case studies – application of medicinal herbs in common diseases

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Science, Philosophy and Human Life
courses.description: A lively, accessible survey of basic issues in critical thinking and philosophy of science as they bear on daily life and our understanding of the world. The course focuses on three general issues: What is science and how is it different from superstition and pseudoscience? How are theories supported by evidence? and Does science give us the truth about reality? Discussions will address topics such as astrology, fortune-telling, and fengshui; parapsychology, extrasensory perception, and ghosts; creationism vs. evolutionary theory; science, religion, and mystical experience; miracle cures, folk medicine, and medical quackery; relativism and truth; scientific progress, scientific revolutions, and rationality; and whether atoms and black holes really exist.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken PHIL4183.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Describe the nature of science, scientific explanation, and scientific method.
Understand some of the basic issues in philosophy of science.
Explain how science is different from superstition and pseudoscience.
Apply critical thinking skills to scientific issues in daily life.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding Science Inquiry:
1. 1 A case: Semmelweis’s work on childbed fever
2. Theories
2. 1 Theoretical Models:
a. Scale Models: DNA
b. Analog Models: Atoms theory
c. Theoretical Models: Newtonian mechanics
2. 2 Theoretical Hypotheses
2. 3 Laws, Theories, and Generalizations: Mendelian Genetics
3. Justifying Scientific Theories
3. 1 Testing Newton’s Theory: Halley’s Comet
3. 2 What makes a good test?
3. 3 Celestial Mechanics and the Phlogiston
4. Fallacies of Theory Testing
4. 1 The Delphi Fallacy: Vague Predictions
4. 2 The Jeane Dixon Fallacy: Multiple Predictions
4. 3 Astrology
4. 4 The Patchwork Quilt Fallacy: Conspiracy Theories
4. 5 The Ad Hoc Rescue: Failed Predictions
4. 6 Justification by Elimination: Extraterrestrial Visitation Revisited
5. Relativism, Truth, and Reality
5. 1 Reality is socially constructed: New Agers
5. 2 Reality is constituted by conceptual Schemes: Conceptual Relativists
5. 3 Facing Reality: Scientific Realism
6. Justifying Statistical Hypotheses
6. 1 Estimation: Polling
6. 2 Problems with Survey Sampling
6. 3 Testing Statistical Hypotheses
7. Justifying Causal Hypotheses
7. 1 Saccharin and Cancer
7. 2 Causal Hypotheses and Randomized Design
7. 3 Effectiveness and Statistical Significance
(Core content: at least 5 of the above topics)

courses.description: This course covers various issues related to climate and climate change, such as how it is related to our lives, our changing climate in the past, sea level rise, impacts of stratospheric ozone hole and global warming, El Niño events and disastrous climate extremes, tropical cyclones, and our responses to climate change.This course intends to enable students to become knowledgeable in the debate on global environmental change and the relevant adaptation and mitigation strategies, which can provide a clearer understanding of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, especially SDG#13 Climate Action. It can also better prepare them to make informed decisions in their career and personal life in the future complex society where resolving the ever-increasing demand for energy and the preservation of the integrity of the environment and natural resources will be a foremost concern. The technological and policy solutions discussed will also help contribute to address SDG#7 Affordable and Clean Energy as well as SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Science, IDA+X Double Maj. Prog., ASEI+X Double Maj. Prog. or MASE+X Double Maj. Prog.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #7 Affordable and Clean Energy
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, you should be able to
describe basic features of the earth system
explain the possible reasons for the occurrence of different types of weather and climate phenomena
describe the different types of extreme weather
describe the tools used to (a) identify the past, and (b) predict and project future changes in weather and climate
explain how these tools can be used to estimate the impacts of climate change on the different types of extreme weather
identify the scientific meaning behind different types of climate science data (e.g., rising sea level) and their limitations as non-science students
explore the possible human footprint on the natural variability of climate
understand the discussion behind the adaptation and mitigation strategies towards the global environmental change, contributing to the understanding and pursuit of SDG#13 Climate Action, SDG#7 Clean and Affordable Energy, and SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1 : Introduction
This part introduces basic ideas of the meaning of climate, climate change, weather, extreme weather, human interaction with the climate.
Part 2 : The Earth System and Forcings of Weather and Climate
This part discusses the basic components of the earth system such as the land surface cover, the ocean and the atmosphere, also features of each component and the interactions between them. Various types of natural and anthropogenic forcings for the climate, including the sun, orbits of the earth, atmospheric and oceanic oscillations, anthropogenic forcings and urbanization are examined.
Part 3 : Extreme Weather
This part includes extreme weather such as heavy precipitation, cold surge, heat wave and tropical cyclones, their features including their intensities and occurring frequencies and the extent of their effect on human societies.
Part 4 : Tools to Study and Predict Weather and Climate and their Changes
This part explores different tools to study the past and future climate. Tools including analyzed observational data presented on charts such as sea-level change and atmospheric methane concentration change for the recent decades are illustrated. For the period before the recent decades where modern measuring devices were not available, proxy tools such as tree rings, corals and ice cores can be used to estimate the past climate. For the future climate, prediction tools such as computer simulations are covered.
Part 5 : Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies Towards Global Environmental Change
This part mentions different options in terms of adaptation and mitigation strategies available and in the future scenarios. Their costs and effectiveness are discussed.

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Viewing Communication from Speech Therapy
courses.description: One in every 10 people suffers from at least a kind of communication disorder. It is almost inevitable for people to have encountered individuals with unclear speech, hoarse voice, stuttering, autism spectrum disorder, hearing impairment and dementia etc. in their lifetime. Students without a background in speech and hearing sciences may not have solid understanding of the essentials of human communication and its disorders. This course thus aims to provide tailor-made content suiting all students to cover the fundamentals of these topics from the perspective of speech-language-pathology. The course consists of 3 major components. The first one brings out the essential elements in normal communication. The second component covers what goes wrong in the chain of communication which leads to various communication disorders. The third component introduces various communication disorders in terms of the general characteristics and the practical tips on how to interact with them through case studies. By learning the essential elements of effective communication skills as well as gaining knowledge on how to facilitate interaction with people who have diverse communication and educational needs, this course also helps students to better understand the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) relating to #3 Good Health and Well-being, #4 Inclusive Quality Education and #10 Reduced Inequalities.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have taken LING3208 or UGEC3928. 
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #4 Quality Education
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
courses.academic_org: Dept of Otor, Head & Neck Sur
courses.learning_outcomes:
Throughout the course, students will be able to achieve the following objectives through readings, lectures, team discussions, and group work:
1. Identify the various processes involved in successful human communication, including the basic anatomical, neurological, and physiological underpinnings of communication. This will help promote SDG#3 - Good Health and Wellbeing by teaching students relevant strategies to foster positive mental health and well-being.
2. Explain how the breakdown in specific processes can lead to different communication disorders, including behavioral analyses. This will help promote SDG#4 - Quality Education by helping students understand how inclusive education is possible with different approaches.
3. Describe the communication, language, and speech characteristics of individuals with different communication disorders, promoting both SDG#4 - Quality Education and SDG#10 - Reduced Inequalities.
4. Summarize the basic principles of communicating with populations facing various difficulties, promoting empathy and diversity and aligning with SDG#4 and SDG#10.
5. Apply the fundamental knowledge gained in improving one's own communication skills, promoting SDG#3 - Good Health and Wellbeing.
courses.course_syllabus:
Course syllabus
Topic
Contents/ fundamental concepts
Introduction to human communication
(SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being)
Speech-language-pathology and communication chain including stages of prelinguistic, language decoding, motor programming, motor execution, transmission, reception, perception, language decoding and message interpretation.
Defining Communication / Language / Speech
Essential elements of effective communication including the basic anatomical, neurological, and physiological underpinnings
Disruption of the communication chain leading to various communication disorders
(SDG#4 Quality education, SDG#10 Reduce inequalities)
Resultant disorders at a glance
Detailed description on each of the following disorder groups in terms of a) how fundamental concepts are used by Speech Therapists; b) the role of anatomical, neurological and physiological functions in each disorder; c) behavioral and linguistic analyses; d) resultant communication difficulties; e) how to deal with their difficulties using evidenc-based practice
Cognitive communication disorders
Dementia
Autism Spectrum Disorder
Down Syndrome
Stroke / Cerebral Vascular Accident
Cleft lip and palate
Speech Sound Disorder
Voice Disorder
Stuttering
Cerebral Palsy
Hearing Impairment
General characteristics and case studies
(SDG#4 Quality education, SDG#10 Reduce inequalities)
Characteristics from the perspective of communication, language and speech. Practical tips on how to interact with different population groups with various communication disorders through case studies so that students could feel empathy for and show solidarity with them
Effective communication skills
Non-verbal communication
Verbal communication

courses.title: Getting to Know Speech and Language Impairment and the Role of Speech Therapist
courses.description: A communication disorder is an impairment in the ability to receive, send, process, and comprehend concepts or verbal, nonverbal and graphic symbol systems. A communication disorder may be evident in the processes of hearing, language, and/or speech. A communication disorder may range in severity from mild to profound.Specifically, speech and language impairment (SLI) refers to any one or combination of the following conditions that may lead to communication difficulties – a) speech sound disorders, b) voice disorders, c) fluency disorders, d) language disorders. Students with SLI may encounter difficulties in communicating effectively with others, which may affect one’s self-esteem and development of social relationships. They may have difficulties in understanding and / or giving oral presentations, struggle in following rapid verbal exchanges which may limit their participation in classes. They may also lack confidence in speaking in front of public or a large group of people. They may thus have trouble adapting to the course work and university life. This is partially attributable to the lack of awareness of SLI among university students and teachers. The course aims to provide general education on knowledge and skills relating to daily communications with students with Speech and Language Impairment (SLI) in academic or social settings, and facilitate equal access to quality education. This course is an SDG-GE course, which aims to promote good health and well-being in the university population, reduce inequality among students with different abilities, and thus facilitate equal access to quality education. The course also helps students to understand the social and economic considerations relevant to speech and language impairment (SLI).
courses.enrollment_requirement: Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #4 Quality Education
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
Virtual Teaching & Learning Course
courses.academic_org: Dept of Otor, Head & Neck Sur
courses.learning_outcomes:
Objectives:
This course aims to provide general education on knowledge and skills relating to daily communications with students with Speech and Language Impairment (SLI) in academic or social settings.
Learning outcomes:
After completing the 1-unit online general education course, students would:
Be aware of and sensitive to special educational needs in campus (SDG 3)
Know and understand the characteristics of, and general difficulties encountered by students with speech and language disorders (SDG 4)
Develop the communication skills and strategies to interact with individuals with speech and language disorders in academic or social settings
Foster positive values of respect, empathy, and inclusion (SDG 10)
Be aware of the social and economic considerations relevant to SLI, thus contribute to reducing inequalities and promoting good health and well-being in the society
Promote self-directed and community-engaged learning via learning in the online mode
Encourage lifelong learning and continue to acquire communication skills with individuals with speech and language disorders in the society
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Contents / Fundamental Concepts
Speech and Language Disorder
To introduce the overall concepts and definition of different terminologies relating to Speech, Language and Communication Disorders
Why does understanding Communication Disorders matter?
What is Speech and Language Disorder?
The overall concepts and definition of Speech and Language Impairment (SLI)
The different aspects and perspectives of SLI
The role of Speech Therapists in the management of Speech and Language Disorders
Supporting students with Speech and Language Disorder
Speech Sound Disorders
How clearly can you speak?
What are Speech Sound Disorders?
The definition, prevalence, anatomy and physiology, and possible causes of Speech Sound Disorders
The different aspects of Speech Sound Disorders
Talking with craniofacial anomalies
Muscle control and speech
The role of Speech Therapists in the management of Speech Sound Disorders
Supporting students with Speech Sound Disorders
Voice Disorders
What happens when your voice fails?
What are Voice Disorders?
The definition, prevalence, anatomy and physiology, and possible causes of Voice Disorders
The different aspects of Voice Disorders
The role of Speech Therapists in the management of Voice Disorders
Supporting people with voice issues: How can you help yourself and friends?
Fluency Disorders
Why do some people stutter?
What are Fluency Disorders?
The definition, prevalence, anatomy and physiology, and possible causes of Fluency Disorders
The different aspects of Fluency Disorders
The role of Speech Therapists in the management of Fluency Disorders
Tips for helping yourself and friends with stuttering
Language Disorders
What are Language Disorders?
Language Disorders uncovered: What every student should know
Do you have developmental Language Disorders?
What do they mean? Understanding language in Autism Spectrum Disorder
Understanding attention deficit / hyperactivity disorder through language
Dissecting language characteristics in hearing loss
The role of Speech Therapists in the management of Language Disorders
The support for students with Language Disorders

courses.subject: UGEB
courses.title: Exploring the Enigmatic Oceans
courses.description: This course aims to provide an overview of the oceans and the roles of natural and anthropogenic impacts on shaping the physical and biological aspects of the oceans. The main themes of the course include the ocean processes, the marine ecosystems and their inhabitants, and the relationships between oceans and mankind. Emphasis will be placed on how natural processes shape the oceans, how the inhabitants survive the marine environment, how we depend on the oceans, the impact of anthropogenic processes on the oceans, and how the future of mankind is affected by the oceans. Examples of topics covered include: the Earth and the oceans, ecosystems of the oceans, marine organisms and their adaptations to the marine environment, exploitation of the oceans, and the management and conservation of the oceans. Altogether, this course also aims to raise awareness and promote the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to SDG#13 Climate Action and SDG#14 Life Below Water. A laboratory visit to the Simon F.S. Li Marine Science Laboratory will be included to demonstrate the methodology and instruments used in marine research.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for majors in School of Life Sciences; not for students in the following concentration areas of NSCI: Biological Sciences; Biotechnology; Environmental Studies; and Food and Nutrition.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
courses.course_syllabus:
Theme 1: The Earth, the Oceans & Ocean Processes
Contents: (i) overview of the Earth and the major oceans, zonation of the ocean and the respective physical and chemical parameters; (ii) the ocean processes and how their interactions shape global conditions such as climates & weather, and (iii) natural cycling of various elements.
Theme 2: Marine Ecosystems
Contents: (i) overview of the characteristics of the marine environment; (ii) coastal ecosystems such as mangroves and coral reefs etc, (iii) pelagic ecosystems such as the open ocean and the deep ocean, and (iv) the hydrothermal vent and cold seep ecosystems.
Theme 3: Marine Organisms
A variety of marine organisms will be discussed, in particular (i) the plankton and their importance; (ii) organisms which show specific adaptation to the marine environment; and (iii) whales and dolphins. Emphasis will be placed on the interactions of the organisms with the environment and their survival, and the impact of mankind on the organisms.
Theme 4: Ocean and Man
Contents: (i) exploitation and conservation of the resources from the oceans; (ii) fisheries/whaling and aquaculture as means of obtaining food from the sea; (iii) organisms threatened by anthropogenic impact and the concepts of endangered organisms; and (iv) marine pollution, remediation and climate actions.
